Sep 06, 2018( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The September episode of the Zacks Ultimate Strategy Session will be available for viewing no later than Thursday, September 13. Sheraz Mian, Tracey Ryniec, Ryan McQueeney and Kevin Cook cover the investment landscape from several angles in this popular event. Don't miss your chance to hear: • Tracey and Ryan Agree to Disagree on how risky it is to invest in companies with visionary CEOs • Sheraz answers your questions in Zacks Mailbag • Sheraz and Ryan choose one portfolio to give feedback for improvement • And much more Remember, we need your input. Please submit your questions for Zacks Mailbag and Portfolio Makeover by Friday morning, September 7. Email now to mailbag@zacks.com; Then log on to Zacks.com and bookmark this page.

Congressional testimonies from a couple tech bigwigs gave investors enough reason to pull profits from the space on Wednesday, handing the NASDAQ its worst session in weeks. Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg and Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey were in Washington today and getting grilled by lawmakers on election tampering, privacy issues and bias, among other topics. The market's real fear, though, is the threat of increased regulation for some of the biggest engines of this strong economy. But it wasn't just social media names taking it on the chin. Technology in general was being sold, leading to a 1.19% plunge in the NASDAQ to 7995.2. There's not much this index can do when all of the FANGs pull back at once. The last time the NASDAQ slipped by more than 1% was during the Turkey mess back in mid-August. Tech also has a big stake in the S...but that index managed to slide by only 0.28% to 2888.6. The Dow bounced around more than its counterparts and actually finished with a gain of 0.09% to 25,975. While these testimonies were the big news today, the market is still keeping a close eye on trade. The U.S. and Canada got back to negotiations today after failing to work out a deal last week. President Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau are taking hard lines on the issue with both pretty much saying that no agreement is better than a bad agreement. And of course, there's still $200 billion worth of new tariffs that could be imposed on Chinese goods this week. Today's Portfolio Highlights: Stocks Under $10: The market was not happy with early results for a gene-editing trial from Sangamo BioSciences (SGMO). As a result, shares got shellacked on Wednesday and dropped more than 23%. SGMO was one of the best performers in the portfolio and Brian Bolan wanted to hold onto the name until it reached about $25. But biotech can be extremely volatile, and the editor doesn't want to risk any more of this impressive profit. He sold SGMO today and banked an approximately 55% return. Home Run Investor: When you're heavily invested in tech, a day like this has you looking for a little diversification. Brian Bolan doesn't think today's tech selloff is a big deal, but it's just a good reminder that balance is key. urn:contentItem:5S05-YBB1-JD34-V1C9-00000-00Tougher laws sought for social media firms;CYBER BULLYING2018-03-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:53ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Tougher laws sought for social media firmsCYBER BULLYINGFergus Hunter

Social media giants already under siege over privacy concerns would face stiff financial penalties and tougher legal requirements to remove abusive material under the recommendations of a parliamentary inquiry into cyber bullying.

The inquiry into the adequacy of existing criminal laws around cyber bullying by the Senate's legal and constitutional affairs committee was triggered late last year by the suicide of Adelaide schoolgirl Libby Bell after an alleged bullying campaign that took place in person and on Facebook, Instragram and Snapchat.

The Labor and crossbench-dominated committee has recommended the government "place and maintain regulatory pressure on social media platforms to both prevent and quickly respond to cyber bullying material on their platform, including through the use of significant financial penalties where insufficient progress is achieved".

It also said the companies should have a legal duty of care for their users - giving people a right to seek compensation in the case of a breach - and be compelled to publish data on cyber bullying complaints they have received and acted on.

But DIGI, the industry body representing Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube and other tech companies in Australia, resisted the push for tougher regulations saying the laws were adequate.

"We understand the desire for greater transparency about the work the industry does to keep our community safe," DIGI's managing director Nicole Buskiewicz said.

"However, we are concerned that the Senate committee has acted against expert advice offered by the anti-bullying experts, legal organisations and police agencies who testified that the current legislative framework is sufficient to deal with cyber bullying from a regulatory perspective."

Ms Buskiewicz said the industry was committed to investing in prevention of bullying and harmful behaviour on its platforms.

The findings on the need to prevent cyber bullying come as Facebook weathers a global storm over its handling of users' data.

Law firm Maurice Blackburn said tougher regulation was needed because social media companies were not being held to account for bullying on their platforms.

"Imposing a duty of care that has real consequences we believe can make a difference to these big tech companies playing an urgent and long overdue role in minimising bullying and inappropriate behaviour on their social media platforms," Maurice Blackburn employment law principal Josh Bornstein said.

Government senators disagreed with the recommendations for tougher regulation and penalties, saying social media companies were aware of the risks of cyber bullying.

urn:contentItem:5VV9-NTK1-JCBW-N1MS-00000-00Tough regulation will help, not hurt, big tech;Giants such as Facebook will cope with Online Harms legislation while others cannot, argue Matthew Field and Harry de Quetteville2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:53ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;SPORTPg. 5Tough regulation will help, not hurt, big techGiants such as Facebook will cope with Online Harms legislation while others cannot, argue Matthew Field and Harry de Quetteville

It is the regulator's dilemma: how to foster innovation yet curb excess; how to impose rules without making them so onerous that only the biggest companies can comply - or hire teams to get round them, water them down, lobby for change, and withstand long and expensive legal disputes.

The Government's long-awaited Online Harms white paper is keenly aware of this dilemma.

But if it seems to be a case of damned if you do, damned if you don't, Jeremy Wright at the Department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, and Sajid Javid, the Home Secretary, insist they can have it both ways. "Innovation and safety online are not mutually exclusive," they say in the White Paper.

Perhaps. For this is now a political as much as a technological battle. "Duty of Care" is a phrase which today features as often on front pages as in the business pages. It has been the subject of a long campaign at The Telegraph. Yet now that it is a matter of policy, cited 53 times in the White Paper's 98 pages, there are questions within the industry about whether that policy has been fully considered, or is merely reflex reaction to growing public outrage.

"People see tech as a political football to be kicked around," one disgruntled insider said yesterday after digesting the White Paper. Not that its tone came as much of a surprise to him. He'd been briefed beforehand by Whitehall sources. "I was told: 'The Home Secretary plans to thrash you.'" The potential sanctions are indeed draconian. Far from bland, mealymouthed proposals, here is red meat - from making senior executives personally responsible, to blocking their services altogether. If Britain ever stopped Facebook reaching these shores, the legal basis would lie in this White Paper. Not that Mr Javid and Mr Wright intend their formula for Britain alone. As they make clear, they want their proposals to become the basis of "new, global approaches for online safety".

That certainly does not lack ambition. Moreover, as well as targeting tech bosses and blocking their sites, they propose to ease the way for aggressive class-action suits, calling them "super-complaints" with tech companies paying for the privilege. "The regulator will be funded by industry," it notes. What is "the industry"? Answer: "Companies that allow users to share or discover user-generated content or interact with each other online". That is great swathes of the internet, from giant to start-up.

The breadth and depth of such regulatory power is, understandably, creating powerful digital shock waves. "We are really concerned about the scope of this," says Dom Hallas, executive director of the Coalition for a Digital Economy. "It really is very broad, it covers virtually everything."

He is referring not just to scale of companies affected, but the content they host. Acts of terror, such as the Christchurch mosque shootings last month, were broadcast on Facebook using its Live video service, and the footage initially spread faster than it, and other sites such as YouTube, could remove it.

Not all dangerous material is so easy to identify for suppression. Yet the White Paper does not shy from clamping down on content that it deems merely "unacceptable".

"Other online behaviours or content, even if they may not be illegal in all circumstances, can also cause serious harm," it notes. Unacceptable but not illegal? "They want [tech companies] to ban material the Government dare not ban itself," says Jim Killock, president of the online advocacy Open Rights Group. "If this material is harmful, why isn't the Government banning it?" To some, like Mark Littlewood, director general at the Institute of Economic Affairs, this is the beginning of the age of censorship. "These draconian regulations will do more harm than good, ushering in new levels of censorship and killing innovation along the way," he said.

And such fears of overreach are also being leapt on by big tech companies. "We need proposals that are targeted and practical to implement … we also need to protect freedom of speech and the services consumers love," said a spokesman for the Internet Association, which represents 40 tech companies including Google and Facebook.

Why then, do such complaints ring a little hollow? Possibly it is because, while they may disagree on some of the terms, broadly the world's largest technology companies have recently supported calls for greater regulation. They want states to help them set the rules, recognising that, frankly, networks of billions of users require a level of mature governance that organisations months and years old cannot muster.

Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook chief executive, last month called for a "more active role for governments and regulators", while Amazon, Google, Twitter's Jack Dorsey and others have all begun to nod along with the sentiment that policing the content on their sites is better left to governments. Yesterday, Mr Javid and Mr Wright obliged. "Privately run platforms have become akin to public spaces," the White Paper suggested. "Some of these companies now acknowledge their responsibility to be guided by norms and rules developed by democratic societies."

Such harmony may seem odd. But there is good reason for the world's biggest tech companies to celebrate yesterday's announcement. It is not the fact of state intervention Mr Zuckerberg et al favour, it is the manner of it.

Because any successful companies "that allow users to share or discover user-generated content or interact with each other online" quickly generate vast amounts of data. Huge quantities of data to check - some of which, like text, may be reasonably simple to check, some of which, like photos and videos, may present far greater problems.

The only possible solution is technology - automated vetting through sophisticated artificial intelligence. And guess which companies have the best AI? Facebook and Google have not sat still in the face of threatened regulation. They have already worked on developing the most advanced software that can immediately detect and remove "hashed" - essentially digitally watermarked - illegal content such as child pornography or terrorist videos.

"We haven't waited for regulation, we've created new technology, hired experts and specialists and ensured our policies are fit for the evolving challenges we face online," Claire Lilley, Google's public policy manager, said yesterday.

Such dominance is legal as well as algorithmic. "Most companies in the market, certainly small British companies, will not be able to compete with Facebook," says Mr Hallas. "The Government is accidentally entrenching the dominance of the largest internet companies that have the most lawyers."

Such unintended consequences would hit smaller companies, and consumers - indeed, almost everyone but the large tech companies many people currently view as the chief villains of the piece.

"In its drive to make the internet 'safe', the Government seems not to recognise its proposals don't regulate social media companies, they regulate social media users," Mr Killock said.

And it is not just the White Paper.

The Cairncross review into journalism in the digital age and ongoing plans for a Digital Services Tax are helping to contribute to a sense that it is open season for other hosts of digital content.

Who will survive? As though he were poor and powerless, Mark Zuckerberg has reached out a trembling hand and asked for help. "Every day, we make decisions about what speech is harmful, what constitutes political advertising and how to prevent sophisticated cyber attacks," he said last month. "But if we were starting from scratch, we wouldn't ask companies to make these judgments alone."

For all its laudable intent, the Online Harms white paper has now given him precisely what he wants. It dilutes his company's responsibility while setting out rules, fees and fines that it is in an unrivalled position to meet. Rivals, however, may be less content. The regulator's dilemma is far from resolved.

urn:contentItem:5VPR-9NS1-DXVP-V0BV-00000-00Tough talk and naked mannequins2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:53ZLexisNexisNEWSLETTERSTough talk and naked mannequinsDan Morain

Good morning, California. Ben Christopher is sitting in for Dan Morain, who is on assignment today.

"There is a protocol of death and an administration of death in the state of California, and it consumes the court's time, it consumes the criminal justice system, it exhausts the soul and the pocketbook. I would ultimately like to shut down that system of death."—Gov. Gavin Newsom in a conference call this week with reporters from ethnic news outlets, musing on a possible plan to ban new death sentences in local criminal cases, according to The Los Angeles Times.

Newsom vs. the death penalty

Gov. Gavin Newsom could order prosecutors not to seek capital punishment.

Doubling down on the moratorium he recently issued on executions, Gov. Gavin Newsom told reporters this week he's also considering a ban on death sentences in local criminal cases, yet another sign that California is swinging away from the state's once-reflexive toughness on crime.

* Making good on his musings, shared on a conference call with ethnic media on Tuesday and more widely reported by The Los Angeles Times on Thursday, could conceivably put Newsom at odds with Attorney General Xavier Becerra.

The attorney general must enforce state laws, capital punishment among them, and last year, Becerra sought the death penalty for a mass murder in Seal Beach, The Times noted:

"While it is not entirely clear how Newsom would implement such an order, he either could have Becerra direct local district attorneys not to seek the death penalty or order Becerra to not defend appeals. Both approaches would probably face legal challenges."

------------

Advertisement

------------

The crime wave that wasn't

The 1990s "super-predator" panic didn't pan out as Californians feared.

Juvenile crime rates have plummeted, leaving California with thousands of empty juvenile detention beds—and the attendant fixed costs, The San Francisco Chronicle reports.

So much for those "super-predator" youths California policymakers predicted in the tough-on-crime 1990s. Over the past three decades, the arrest rate among youths has dropped 84 percent, compared to only 9 percent for middle-aged adults, The Chronicle finds, citing statewide data:

* Homicides dropped 83 percent between 1995 to 2017.

* Violent felony arrests declined 68 percent between 1994 and 2017.

* In 39 of 43 California counties with juvenile halls, facilities were less than 50 percent full last year.

The decline happened across the country "almost regardless of what local, state or national policies were adopted," said Mike Males of the Center on Juvenile and Criminal Justice. (For a deeper analysis, see Males' commentary for CALmatters here.)

Now counties are on the hook for nearly 9,000 empty juvenile detention beds, and per capita detention costs are so high that some counties are spending the equivalent of an Ivy League degree plus two years of law school for every teen they're holding. After the report posted Thursday, three San Francisco supervisors pledged to close the juvenile hall there.

Los Angeles Democratic Sen. Holly Mitchell: "I think we need to figure out what to do with that excess property and figure out what a new environment looks like."

Mark Varela, chief probation officer in Ventura County: "It's really the opposite of what we thought it would be. We're all kind of scratching our heads over what we're going to do with all the extra space."

------------

Advertisement

------------

Offshore oil fight

Another Trump threat on California offshore drilling.

The Trump administration is trying to "streamline" a federal regulation that would limit California's ability to stop new offshore drilling, The Los Angeles Times reports:

"The administration appears to be considering limits to the scope of states' review powers and a shorter period of time to process an appeal. The full extent of its plans is unclear."

The skirmish is the latest between California and the Trump administration over fossil fuel exploration in the Pacific.

* 2017: The Trump administration begins reviewing locations in the Pacific for new lease sales. Six sales are proposed off the California coast.

* 2018: The Legislature passes a bill, with bipartisan support, "strongly and unequivocally" opposing the leasing plan.

Earlier this week, 17 U.S. Senate Democrats including California's Sen. Dianne Feinstein and Sen. Kamala Harris wrote an open letter to the acting Secretary of the Interior, David Bernhardt, asking him to explain his position on offshore drilling.

* President Trump has nominated Bernhardt to formally replace the last Interior secretary, Ryan Zinke. Californians know Bernhardt as a lobbyist for oil and agribusiness. His confirmation hearing is scheduled for next Thursday.

Saber rattling the First Amendment

President Trump signs an executive order on campus free speech.

President Donald Trump—surrounded by conservative college students including a few from UC Berkeley—signed an executive order yesterday to "ensure" that universities that receive public funding "promote free inquiry, including through compliance with all applicable Federal laws, regulations, and policies."

Trump: "Federal agencies will use their authority under various grant-making programs to ensure that public universities protect—cherish—protect the First Amendment and the First Amendment rights of their students or risk losing billions and billions of dollars."

Policy consequences are unclear. The order doesn't specify how agencies should "ensure" promotion of free speech—or what that would even look like. Funding cuts would no doubt be challenged in court. Californians responded:

* Janet Napolitano, UC President: "We do not need the federal government to mandate what already exists: our longstanding, unequivocal support for freedom of expression."

* Harmeet Dhillon, RNC National Committeewoman from California who has sued UC Berkeley: "It is outrageous for public universities to with one hand choke free speech, and with the other, take federal dollars…this is long overdue."

Speaking of free speech: A Republican legislator has introduced a resolution calling for the removal of a tenured UC Davis English professor who, in the past, has cheered the death of law enforcement officers.

From HR 22: "Incitements to violence are not protected speech under the First Amendment and the First Amendment does not entitle a person to teach impressionable students at a taxpayer-supported university."

Equal pay for equal play

Is a level playing field worth the loss of female-only sporting events?

Women surfers scored big in California last year when an obscure government commission decided it would only lease a public beach to the Mavericks surf competition if men and women were awarded equal cash prizes.

* They seemed headed for another win this year when a bill was introduced to require equal prize money for men and women at any sporting event on state-owned land.

But now the push to go further has opened a broader debate over how to advance equality for women in male-dominated sports—and whether men should be included in all-female competitions. The debate extends far beyond the Capitol and, for that matter, surfing:

* Sabrina Brennan, co-founder of the Committee for Equity in Women's surfing, argues that single-sex athletic events perpetuate inequality. She wants the bill to require that all sporting events on state land include categories for both men and women.

* Assemblywoman Tasha Boerner Horvath wants to preserve female-only sporting events meant to empower girls and women in sports dominated by men.

Explore the debate with CALmatters' Laurel Rosenhall.

Thurmond talks charters

State schools chief Tony Thurmond, right, with CALmatters' Ricardo Cano.

Anyone counting on Tony Thurmond, the state's top public school administrator, to soften his stance on California charter schools after the November election is in for a disappointment.

* Thurmond appeared Thursday evening at the Commonwealth Club Thursday with CALmatters' education reporter, Ricardo Cano. When Cano mentioned charters, public schools that are privately managed, the superintendent of public instruction jokingly pretended to flee—feigning an aversion to the emotional topic. But after the laughter died down, Thurmond's preference was clear.

Thurmond: "The purpose of charter schools was to lend itself to some innovation…[but] I do not believe that education is an environment for competition."

"There is a role" for charters, Thurmond said, but he repeated a campaign pledge to push for a controversial policy that would let districts consider their financial impact on traditional schools in determining whether to approve a charter. Charter advocates fear the criteria would make it easier to say no to new charter schools.

* Thurmond's fiercely fought 2018 victory over former charter school CEO Marshall Tuck was portrayed during the campaign as a referendum on charters—a characterization that both candidates rejected.

* But of the $30 million in outside money spent on behalf of Tuck (or against Thurmond) most came from pro-charter groups, while Thurmond drew much of his support from public school teachers unions who oppose charters.

CALmatters will have more coverage on last night's conversation later today.

Take a Number: 1.4 million

Those federal tax cuts haven't helped California's rental crisis, a new report says.

California is short 1.4 million rental units, even with last year's massive package of housing bills, the California Housing Partnership reports.

* The non-profit measured the number of renters making less than the average income in their area and compared it to the number of rental units available that would allow them to spend less than 30 percent of their income on rent.

Federal policy shares the blame for that 1.4 million difference: One of the state's biggest affordable housing programs is the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit program, which allows investors to reduce their tax bill in exchange for backing construction of affordable units.

* Big federal tax cuts for corporations and the very rich have diminished the appetite for tax-reducing investments.

Among Gov. Gavin Newsom's proposals to address the state housing crisis: Convince big tech companies to pick up the slack.

That'll show 'em

Jason Windus, "naked garden party" host.

When Santa Rosa city officials told Jason Windus that he would have to shorten the fence he had just built, Windus did what any aggrieved homeowner would do—if they happened to have a collection of "anatomically correct" mannequins.

Windus: "I guess the average person would get angry and cop resentment? I throw a naked party in my yard."

The five mannequins in the buff (six, if you count the disembodied head) have fortunately been a hit with the neighbors, The Sacramento Bee reports.

* The tony enclave of Hillsborough, south of San Francisco, is less understanding. The owner of the iconic domed "Flintstone House," familiar to I-280 commuters, was recently sued by the city for creating a "public nuisance" by filling her backyard with dinosaur and Flintstone statues. Now she's suing back, fighting for her right to prehistoric lawn ornaments.

Commentary at CALmatters

Glenn Sacks, teacher at James Monroe High School and co-chair of United Teachers of Los Angeles at Monroe High: Some charter parents assert their children's charter school experience is positive. I can believe it. But sincere charter parents need to understand that while for some students charters can be beneficial, their overall impact on public education is destructive.

Ashley Gould, chief administrative officer at JUUL Labs: The JUUL system represents an unprecedented opportunity to help adult smokers switch off combustible cigarettes.

Dan Walters, CALmatters: California's Democratic politicians aren't very democratic when it comes to respecting the will of voters.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It is time for us to toss over to MORNINGS WITH MARIA with Maria. Chris Beauchamp, thank you so much. Thank you for being with us today. Dagen, it's yours.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I can't wait to see you two ladies coming up, Gerri, because you've got a really good story for us.

WILLIS: Yes, ma'am.

MCDOWELL: It will make everyone in this country really angry, right?

WILLIS: That is right.

MCDOWELL: This is Gerri's wheelhouse. So thank you so much for that Kristine and Gerri. Good morning everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 6th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough talk on trade, China firing back against President Trump, state media blasting the administration saying extortion won't work. President Trump doubling down on his policies over the weekend however at a rally in Ohio.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: But if I didn't do anything with trade, just kept quiet, let them continue to take advantage of us, nobody says anything, I think you would have been up another 40, 50, 60 percent.

But eventually, you would have had to pay the piper eventually. And we're not going to do that, we're going to do something, we're going to make our country so much richer than it's ever been.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Trade uncertainty weighing in on the market a little bit. Futures have turned around however, 17-point gain on the Dow Futures right here right now. Broadly speaking, the markets have shrugged off everything that's been going on with tariffs and the trade fight. This after gains on Wall Street last week, the Dow Industrials and the S&P500 posting gains for five weeks in a row.

In Europe checking on England, France, and Germany, at the moment we have gains across the board as well. The biggest winner, the DAX Index in Germany up one-third of one percent.

In Asia overnight, mixed action, the Shanghai Composite the worst performer there, down one and a third percent in Shanghai.

Devastation in Indonesia, a major earthquake striking, killing dozens of people in more than 100 aftershocks felt throughout the region.

Another scandal for Wells Fargo, this is what I'm talking about, Gerri's going to be up shortly discussing the bank revealed that hundreds of people lost their homes because of a computer glitch. They were foreclosed on unfairly. Let's talk about the compensation, that will be coming up.

And Samsung taking on the iPhone, the tech giant confirming upgrades to its Galaxy Note 9.

And talk about a dream job, the maker of Nutella is hiring tasters. Let's all raise our hands for that.

All of that and so much more coming up this morning. Maslansky & Partners President Lee Carter. PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle. And former CIA Operative, Diligence President Mike Baker. The only reason we booked you is to show the goat video from Boise, there you go.

MIKE BAKER, PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE LLC: Everybody's going crazy about the goat video, rapid goats in Boise, Idaho. It's the best publicity we've had in ages.

But it's a wonderful city, Wall Street Journal called Boise, Idaho--I know people are saying, "What is he talking about?" They call Wall Street -- the called Boise, Idaho the fastest growing city in America and it's true.

MCDOWELL: And it's -- and it's because you have like 80 children and --

BAKER: And we -- who's counting?

MCDOWELL: I'm just -- I'm just joking. But we -- we're going to cover the world for you this morning in the next three hours with Mike, Mitch, and Lee. Great to see all of you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: So on to our top story this hour, trade tensions escalating, Chinese state media bashing President Trump's trade tactic saying policies of extortion and intimidation won't work. The commander-in-chief with a different view of the situation voicing support for his negotiating style saying tariffs are working.

Tweeting just yesterday this, "Tariffs are working big time. Every country on earth wants to take wealth out of the United States always to our detriment. I say as they come, tax them, if they don't want to be taxed, let them make or build the product in the U.S. In either event, it means jobs and great wealth."

"Because of tariffs, we will be able to start paying down large amounts of the $21 trillion in debt accumulated, much by the Obama Administration while at the same time reducing taxes for our people. At minimum, we will make much better trade deals for our country."

Here now is Mark Avallone, President and Founder of Potomac Wealth Advisors. Mark, are you with us?

MARK AVALLONE, PRESIDENT AND FOUNDER, POTOMAC WEALTH ADVISORS: Yes. Good morning, good to be here.

MCDOWELL: Good morning. What do you -- what do you make of this? So far, I don't -- I don't think it's a stretch to say that the market has largely shrugged off what has been going on with the trade fight that started in the spring.

AVALLONE: Well it has shrugged it off, our market's up year-to-date across the board and China's is down. It's down 18 percent the beginning of the year and it's in bear market going back to 2017.

So the Trump strategy is to use our economic strength now while we have it to enact much needed and frankly, much deserved parity. He wants a fair playing field with China. The only problem with the trade policy is he dragged in the Canadians and the E.U. which then you have us against the world.

If we focus on China, keep it more of a microcosm then the stock market appears to say, "Hey, we can manage this. Our economy is strong enough and we'll push higher from here."

MCDOWELL: Mitch, how much runway is the market or investors going to give the Trump Administration because right now we've seen with the job's report on Friday we created on average 215,000 jobs every month, that's faster than the pace that we were at last -- last year, the first seven months of the year which is really incredible for an economy that's been in expansion mode since -- for nine years.

ROSCHELLE: The interesting thing would be in -- I think the reason why the market shrugged it off and to your point on runway is because corporate earnings have been so robust.

But what we're starting to see is the cost of the supply chain understand the market perspective on this, the cost in the supply chain to go up. And if they cannot pass those cost to the customer, meaning customers won't pay an increase price then we're going to see impact corporate profits.

The flip side is, if they can, we're going to see inflation. So, I think we're close to maybe in the next quarter getting to the point where the market's going to have a hard time turning off --

MCDOWELL: Well is that a lose lose because somebody bears that cost, either it's corporations or if it's the consumer. If it's the consumer, is it more -- if the companies can passed those cost on the consumer, is it more, I guess, the impact won't be as severe to the market.

ROSCHELLE: It will -- it certainly won't be. In fact, it will help grow revenue because they're charging more for the products. It may not necessarily help margin, but it will certainly help the top line.

But the challenge is going to be how much can you pay for (INAUDIBLE) before the market pushes back or there's another alternative that starts to erode sales. But Mark, I'm curious your perspective on that.

AVALLONE: Well if it does as you say raise the price of the end good and raising revenues for the corporation, then it is a tax on the consumer. Ultimately it is going to be a drag.

But I think the play here is that are the consumer wages are so strong, the individuals are flushed with cash, we can pay up for this without it slowing down our economy too much. China's limping along.

So one a one-on-one basis, we can power through this. If that wasn't the outlook, we would have seen the stock market pull back by now. The market looks forward and yet it's been up for the year. So I think all the news is out and Wall Street is saying the global growth story that we heard, the I.M. -- from the IMF this year for the G20, from we continue it here from the Fed, the global growth story is strong enough that even if price is raised, it's not going to slow down the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: Mitch already mentioned this, there's a story in the Wall Street Journal today, an article commenting on the strong earnings season. Profits surging at big U.S. firm, strong economy, and tax cuts, fuel gains, and embolden companies to raise prices.

This is a recent report by the UFDA showed nearly three million have come - - individuals have come all for food stamps since President Trump took office. Mark -- Mike Baker, you can see the world in terms of the business that you do.

And Mark briefly mentioned this, that we do have the upper hand because China is so weak right now, because the stock market is greater, their economy is growing a great deal slower, and they are wash in debt. So the timing of this that people act like President Trump might be rash, but there's some wiliness and some intelligence in why we pick right now to take this fight on.

BAKER: I think that's true. I'm heading to Beijing tomorrow morning for a week or so, very curious to kind of get the on the ground response from just the, you know, local folks in business about how they perceive this from their side.

I will say it's not in anybody's interest globally for -- to have an unstable Chinese economy, it just -- it just not. And so --

MCDOWELL: Do you think they blank though? That's been the question that we raise last week, do you think China blanks on this?

BAKER: I think ultimately they do because they're extremely pragmatic and they understand what a chaotic problem they could have if the economy continues to head south.

And with -- a question from Mar is, you mentioned mark the idea that we dragged in Canada and the E.U. into this overall trade issues, trade war, do you think that that was more of a negotiating ploy with the president in terms of overall objective for China or do you think in a sense, you know, there's not really a grand strategy here?

AVALLONE: Well it's tough to say with the president. Maybe he's trying to show the Chinese he's serious about this and hopefully, quietly behind the scenes reaching an agreement.

MCDOWELL: We picked that song because it's one of Mike Baker's top favorite songs of all-time. Final thoughts from our all-stars. Go!

BAKER: Sure. I can confirm that in Boise, we do have the goats gone wild situation under control. It is now safe to go back to Boise, it won't be acoasted by roaming goats. That's all I got.

MCDOWELL: We rank guys -- no, you've got more. Give me something on China real quick.

BAKER: Heading there tomorrow. We'll be back here with you guys in a couple of weeks and we'll be looking forward to talking about what it looks like on the ground there.

MCDOWELL: Are they going to give, are they going to step up and let us actually negotiate different trade deals, Mitch?

ROSCHELLE: The thing that concerns me is growing national debt. We have over $700 billion being refinanced of the next two quarters and that really concerns me.

MCDOWELL: And Federal Reserve is pulling back on its balance sheet at the same time and we're running $1-trillion budget.

ROSCHELLE: This is going to be a trillion-dollar deficit this year.

MCDOWELL: Lee?

CARTER: A lot of criticisms about the polls, and whether or not they're reliable. I think what's important to look at the polls for is for momentum and direction, and it looks like the President has weathered a really tough storm.

MCDOWELL: Indeed, Lee Carter, Mitch Roschelle, and Mike Baker. Thanks to one and all, travel safely, we will see you tomorrer (ph) -- excuse me -- tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts right now. Stuart, it is all yours.

VARNEY: Yes, it is, Dagen, good morning to you, thank you very much, indeed. And good morning, everyone. Investors, how is this to start the week, profit season in full swing, and big companies, their profit is surging.

END

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It is time for us to toss over to MORNINGS WITH MARIA with Maria. Chris Beauchamp, thank you so much. Thank you for being with us today. Dagen, it's yours.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I can't wait to see you two ladies coming up, Gerri, because you've got a really good story for us.

WILLIS: Yes, ma'am.

MCDOWELL: It will make everyone in this country really angry, right?

WILLIS: That is right.

MCDOWELL: This is Gerri's wheelhouse. So thank you so much for that Kristine and Gerri. Good morning everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 6th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough talk on trade, China firing back against President Trump, state media blasting the administration saying extortion won't work. President Trump doubling down on his policies over the weekend however at a rally in Ohio.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: But if I didn't do anything with trade, just kept quiet, let them continue to take advantage of us, nobody says anything, I think you would have been up another 40, 50, 60 percent.

But eventually, you would have had to pay the piper eventually. And we're not going to do that, we're going to do something, we're going to make our country so much richer than it's ever been.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Trade uncertainty weighing in on the market a little bit. Futures have turned around however, 17-point gain on the Dow Futures right here right now. Broadly speaking, the markets have shrugged off everything that's been going on with tariffs and the trade fight. This after gains on Wall Street last week, the Dow Industrials and the S&P500 posting gains for five weeks in a row.

In Europe checking on England, France, and Germany, at the moment we have gains across the board as well. The biggest winner, the DAX Index in Germany up one-third of one percent.

In Asia overnight, mixed action, the Shanghai Composite the worst performer there, down one and a third percent in Shanghai.

Devastation in Indonesia, a major earthquake striking, killing dozens of people in more than 100 aftershocks felt throughout the region.

Another scandal for Wells Fargo, this is what I'm talking about, Gerri's going to be up shortly discussing the bank revealed that hundreds of people lost their homes because of a computer glitch. They were foreclosed on unfairly. Let's talk about the compensation, that will be coming up.

And Samsung taking on the iPhone, the tech giant confirming upgrades to its Galaxy Note 9.

And talk about a dream job, the maker of Nutella is hiring tasters. Let's all raise our hands for that.

All of that and so much more coming up this morning. Maslansky & Partners President Lee Carter. PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle. And former CIA Operative, Diligence President Mike Baker. The only reason we booked you is to show the goat video from Boise, there you go.

MIKE BAKER, PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE LLC: Everybody's going crazy about the goat video, rapid goats in Boise, Idaho. It's the best publicity we've had in ages.

But it's a wonderful city, Wall Street Journal called Boise, Idaho--I know people are saying, "What is he talking about?" They call Wall Street -- the called Boise, Idaho the fastest growing city in America and it's true.

MCDOWELL: And it's -- and it's because you have like 80 children and --

BAKER: And we -- who's counting?

MCDOWELL: I'm just -- I'm just joking. But we -- we're going to cover the world for you this morning in the next three hours with Mike, Mitch, and Lee. Great to see all of you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: So on to our top story this hour, trade tensions escalating, Chinese state media bashing President Trump's trade tactic saying policies of extortion and intimidation won't work. The commander-in-chief with a different view of the situation voicing support for his negotiating style saying tariffs are working.

Tweeting just yesterday this, "Tariffs are working big time. Every country on earth wants to take wealth out of the United States always to our detriment. I say as they come, tax them, if they don't want to be taxed, let them make or build the product in the U.S. In either event, it means jobs and great wealth."

"Because of tariffs, we will be able to start paying down large amounts of the $21 trillion in debt accumulated, much by the Obama Administration while at the same time reducing taxes for our people. At minimum, we will make much better trade deals for our country."

Here now is Mark Avallone, President and Founder of Potomac Wealth Advisors. Mark, are you with us?

MARK AVALLONE, PRESIDENT AND FOUNDER, POTOMAC WEALTH ADVISORS: Yes. Good morning, good to be here.

MCDOWELL: Good morning. What do you -- what do you make of this? So far, I don't -- I don't think it's a stretch to say that the market has largely shrugged off what has been going on with the trade fight that started in the spring.

AVALLONE: Well it has shrugged it off, our market's up year-to-date across the board and China's is down. It's down 18 percent the beginning of the year and it's in bear market going back to 2017.

So the Trump strategy is to use our economic strength now while we have it to enact much needed and frankly, much deserved parity. He wants a fair playing field with China. The only problem with the trade policy is he dragged in the Canadians and the E.U. which then you have us against the world.

If we focus on China, keep it more of a microcosm then the stock market appears to say, "Hey, we can manage this. Our economy is strong enough and we'll push higher from here."

MCDOWELL: Mitch, how much runway is the market or investors going to give the Trump Administration because right now we've seen with the job's report on Friday we created on average 215,000 jobs every month, that's faster than the pace that we were at last -- last year, the first seven months of the year which is really incredible for an economy that's been in expansion mode since -- for nine years.

ROSCHELLE: The interesting thing would be in -- I think the reason why the market shrugged it off and to your point on runway is because corporate earnings have been so robust.

But what we're starting to see is the cost of the supply chain understand the market perspective on this, the cost in the supply chain to go up. And if they cannot pass those cost to the customer, meaning customers won't pay an increase price then we're going to see impact corporate profits.

The flip side is, if they can, we're going to see inflation. So, I think we're close to maybe in the next quarter getting to the point where the market's going to have a hard time turning off --

MCDOWELL: Well is that a lose lose because somebody bears that cost, either it's corporations or if it's the consumer. If it's the consumer, is it more -- if the companies can passed those cost on the consumer, is it more, I guess, the impact won't be as severe to the market.

ROSCHELLE: It will -- it certainly won't be. In fact, it will help grow revenue because they're charging more for the products. It may not necessarily help margin, but it will certainly help the top line.

But the challenge is going to be how much can you pay for (INAUDIBLE) before the market pushes back or there's another alternative that starts to erode sales. But Mark, I'm curious your perspective on that.

AVALLONE: Well if it does as you say raise the price of the end good and raising revenues for the corporation, then it is a tax on the consumer. Ultimately it is going to be a drag.

But I think the play here is that are the consumer wages are so strong, the individuals are flushed with cash, we can pay up for this without it slowing down our economy too much. China's limping along.

So one a one-on-one basis, we can power through this. If that wasn't the outlook, we would have seen the stock market pull back by now. The market looks forward and yet it's been up for the year. So I think all the news is out and Wall Street is saying the global growth story that we heard, the I.M. -- from the IMF this year for the G20, from we continue it here from the Fed, the global growth story is strong enough that even if price is raised, it's not going to slow down the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: Mitch already mentioned this, there's a story in the Wall Street Journal today, an article commenting on the strong earnings season. Profits surging at big U.S. firm, strong economy, and tax cuts, fuel gains, and embolden companies to raise prices.

This is a recent report by the UFDA showed nearly three million have come - - individuals have come all for food stamps since President Trump took office. Mark -- Mike Baker, you can see the world in terms of the business that you do.

And Mark briefly mentioned this, that we do have the upper hand because China is so weak right now, because the stock market is greater, their economy is growing a great deal slower, and they are wash in debt. So the timing of this that people act like President Trump might be rash, but there's some wiliness and some intelligence in why we pick right now to take this fight on.

BAKER: I think that's true. I'm heading to Beijing tomorrow morning for a week or so, very curious to kind of get the on the ground response from just the, you know, local folks in business about how they perceive this from their side.

I will say it's not in anybody's interest globally for -- to have an unstable Chinese economy, it just -- it just not. And so --

MCDOWELL: Do you think they blank though? That's been the question that we raise last week, do you think China blanks on this?

BAKER: I think ultimately they do because they're extremely pragmatic and they understand what a chaotic problem they could have if the economy continues to head south.

And with -- a question from Mar is, you mentioned mark the idea that we dragged in Canada and the E.U. into this overall trade issues, trade war, do you think that that was more of a negotiating ploy with the president in terms of overall objective for China or do you think in a sense, you know, there's not really a grand strategy here?

AVALLONE: Well it's tough to say with the president. Maybe he's trying to show the Chinese he's serious about this and hopefully, quietly behind the scenes reaching an agreement.

We saw that Mexico, we might update the NAFTA Agreement and start being on a friendly playing field again. That's really the hope. You really don't want to take on the entire world. It's either take on China, and focus on these legitimate inequities, technology transfer and others and let's have our allies with us as we try to take on China.

Remember, China's also unfair to the E.U., let's make the E.U. our ally against the number one trade offender and that is China.

CARTER: This is Lee Carter, I -- one of the things that I've been fascinated to watch is that most Americans really have been willing to give the president a long runway here and that's been really surprising because the most part people don't want to take short-term pain in order for the long-term gain.

And China's known to have a long gain, really long gain. We've got election cycle after election cycle after election cycle and investor seem to be giving in the past two. But I'm just wondering how long do you think Americans are going to give this runway before they're going to say, "Wait, this is too much?"

AVALLONE: Well, it's interesting that -- that's a great point because a lot of the Trump voters are the ones that are negatively impacted by this tariff skirmish. You have farmers in the Midwest that voted for Trump that are taking a lot of this.

And some of the manufacturing with the aluminum and steel tariffs could have gone against a lot of his base. But ironically, they are sticking with him and we haven't seen the weakness just yet. China on the other hand doesn't have an election in November nor will they have an election.

So their government can continue to be autocratic and weighed out. So if Trump's playing the long game, he doesn't really have the upper hand in that. I think trying -- we keep saying is, is China going to blink? That's the last thing we should say. China's never going to publicly blink.

We want to work diplomatically behind the scenes and hope to get a favorable outcome without letting the world thing we beat China or they blink because they're not going to blink publicly.

MCDOWELL: Would you add the stocks here Mark, U.S. stocks particularly with the -- again, over the weekend I think that Jamie Dimon the head of J.P. Morgan said that he -- that the -- this country should brace itself for five percent interest rates.

He said that he thinks that the tenure yield should be at four percent right now and we should brace for five, this is we're staring down $1 trillion annual budget deficits and the Treasury is going to be selling a whole wash of debt in the coming weeks.

AVALLONE: Well when I hear those Jamie Dimon comments I said perhaps. But we're in a global economy. With the tenure boomed and the tenure in Japan being, what, less than one half a percent close to zero in Japan.

So we cannot unilaterally raise our rates that rapidly, it's a global economy. There's a subtle currency we're going on where none of these other entities want to raise their currencies, they're not going to (INAUDIBLE) up interest rates. A five percent tenure is not going to happen.

We're lucky if we get to four percent in this country the way we have the foreign pressure in the currency and in the interest rate markets. I think if you invest, you have to look domestically. Our economy is too strong.

I think small caps which earn about 75 percent of their revenue here domestically versus the S&P500 which get about half of their revenues overseas, I think it's a safer place in case this trade skirmish continues.

And, again, since I don't see interest rates going anywhere near four percent in the next 12 months, I think the U.S. economy manages any rate hike and we continue to chug along.

MCDOWELL: Mark, thank you so much, Mark Avallone. And Mitch Roschelle, when you're talking about the debt, the one thing that's on your mind is the amount of supply coming in Treasury.

ROSCHELLE: And also, look who buys them, central bankers are the biggest buyers of our debt and it worries that we're sort of fighting with them on other issues. What if China decides to use how they behave the next Treasury auction as a -- as a weapon.

MCDOWELL: $769 billion in Treasury up for auction over what period of time? I'm reading an e-mail Mitch since --

ROSCHELLE: (INAUDIBLE) your head.

MCDOWELL: No, when is it coming on?

ROSCHELLE: I think it's over the next year. I think that according to the Journal but we can double check that. But that's a big chunk of treasuries that are up for sale and we could see rates go up.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I -- when people always point to Japan and a slow interest rates I'm like, "Yes." But Japan's kind of been in a recession for the last 30 years on and off.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. Since the 80s.

MCDOWELL: Like we don't -- yes, since the late 80s. We kind of hope that we're not Japan.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. Don't use -- don't use Japan as the benchmark please.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Thank you. Thank you very much. Coming up, death and destruction as an earthquake rocks the popular Indonesian resort island. More than 80 people dead. Officials expect that death toll to rise.

And another black eye for Wells Fargo, hundreds of people plunged into foreclosure unfairly because of a software glitch. The new fallout ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A deadly powerful earthquake striking a tourist island in Indonesia. Kristina Partsinevelos has the details. Good morning Kristina.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. And that's right Dagen, at least 91 have been killed after a 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck the Indonesian island of Lombok, hundreds have been injured and thousands displaced as tourists flees the popular island.

The death toll is expected to rise as search and rescue teams expand their efforts. And they can't get a break because that area was still recovering from a deadly 6.4 magnitude earthquake that hit last week.

Goldman Sachs set to name a new co-head of its trading operation, the Wall Street Journal says Jim Esposito will be tapped for the position. The newspaper says the move follows months of leadership on certainty in Goldman's largest division.

Goldman's incoming CEO David Sullivan reportedly could make an announcement this morning. Shares of Goldman Sachs are eight percent this year.

And finally, Tom Cruise and Winnie the Pooh battles for first place at the weekend Box Office.

(VIDEO CLIP)

PARTSINEVELOS: And who do you think won? Tom Cruise came out on top. His new film Mission Impossible Fallout hanging on to the number one spot for the week, the second eek in a row breaking in an estimated $35 million.

Meanwhile, Disney's Christopher Robin fell short of expectations earning $25 million in its opening weekend. And last but not least, the new comedy film, The Spy Who Dumped Me brought home $12.4 million for a third place finish. Rounding up the top five, Mama Mia: Here We Go Ahead and the Equalizer 2. Have you guys any of you seen these movies over the weekend?

BAKER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Well you did -- did you, Mike Baker?

BAKER: Christopher Robin.

MCDOWELL: You did?

CARTER: You did?

BAKER: Well I got three little kids. It looks like I'm going to see Winnie the Pooh. Winnie the Pooh by the way in a real fight would kick Tom Cruise's ass. I don't know if I could say that but I just did.

MCDOWELL: You just said that.

BAKER: I just did. Sorry. There you go.

MCDOWELL: Wait, why would -- I would put my money on Eeyore versus Tom Cruise.

BAKER: Well, yes.

MCDOWELL: Eeyore is my spirit animal.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE)

BAKER: Here we go ahead.

MCDOWELL: Slow and grumpy morning, noon, and night grumpy. Eeyore's in it, isn't he?

BAKER: You know, it's --

ROSCHELLE: Don't ruin it for us.

BAKER: Yes, I won't -- I won't tell you how it ends, let me just put it that way. Right.

ROSCHELLE: Does he get the honey jar off his nose though?

BAKER: If you got kids, who can't like Winnie the Pooh, come on?

MCDOWELL: Would you pay to see Ethan Hunt in Mission Impossible?

BAKER: No. No. But if Damon makes another Bourne movie, I'm there.

MCDOWELL: OK.

BAKER: All right.

MCDOWELL: So Bourne over Mission Impossible.

BAKER: Yes. Yes.
