Fires Explode In Size; Nutella Makers Seeks Testers; Samsung Note 9 "Leak"; Apple Hits $1T Market CapDagen McDowell, Kristina Partsinevelos, Gerri Willis, Jessica Tarlov

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It is time for us to toss over to MORNINGS WITH MARIA with Maria. Chris Beauchamp, thank you so much. Thank you for being with us today. Dagen, it's yours.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I can't wait to see you two ladies coming up, Gerri, because you've got a really good story for us.

WILLIS: Yes, ma'am.

MCDOWELL: It will make everyone in this country really angry, right?

WILLIS: That is right.

MCDOWELL: This is Gerri's wheelhouse. So thank you so much for that Kristine and Gerri. Good morning everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 6th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough talk on trade, China firing back against President Trump, state media blasting the administration saying extortion won't work. President Trump doubling down on his policies over the weekend however at a rally in Ohio.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: But if I didn't do anything with trade, just kept quiet, let them continue to take advantage of us, nobody says anything, I think you would have been up another 40, 50, 60 percent.

But eventually, you would have had to pay the piper eventually. And we're not going to do that, we're going to do something, we're going to make our country so much richer than it's ever been.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Trade uncertainty weighing in on the market a little bit. Futures have turned around however, 17-point gain on the Dow Futures right here right now. Broadly speaking, the markets have shrugged off everything that's been going on with tariffs and the trade fight. This after gains on Wall Street last week, the Dow Industrials and the S&P500 posting gains for five weeks in a row.

In Europe checking on England, France, and Germany, at the moment we have gains across the board as well. The biggest winner, the DAX Index in Germany up one-third of one percent.

In Asia overnight, mixed action, the Shanghai Composite the worst performer there, down one and a third percent in Shanghai.

Devastation in Indonesia, a major earthquake striking, killing dozens of people in more than 100 aftershocks felt throughout the region.

Another scandal for Wells Fargo, this is what I'm talking about, Gerri's going to be up shortly discussing the bank revealed that hundreds of people lost their homes because of a computer glitch. They were foreclosed on unfairly. Let's talk about the compensation, that will be coming up.

And Samsung taking on the iPhone, the tech giant confirming upgrades to its Galaxy Note 9.

And talk about a dream job, the maker of Nutella is hiring tasters. Let's all raise our hands for that.

All of that and so much more coming up this morning. Maslansky & Partners President Lee Carter. PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle. And former CIA Operative, Diligence President Mike Baker. The only reason we booked you is to show the goat video from Boise, there you go.

MIKE BAKER, PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE LLC: Everybody's going crazy about the goat video, rapid goats in Boise, Idaho. It's the best publicity we've had in ages.

But it's a wonderful city, Wall Street Journal called Boise, Idaho--I know people are saying, "What is he talking about?" They call Wall Street -- the called Boise, Idaho the fastest growing city in America and it's true.

MCDOWELL: And it's -- and it's because you have like 80 children and --

BAKER: And we -- who's counting?

MCDOWELL: I'm just -- I'm just joking. But we -- we're going to cover the world for you this morning in the next three hours with Mike, Mitch, and Lee. Great to see all of you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: So on to our top story this hour, trade tensions escalating, Chinese state media bashing President Trump's trade tactic saying policies of extortion and intimidation won't work. The commander-in-chief with a different view of the situation voicing support for his negotiating style saying tariffs are working.

Tweeting just yesterday this, "Tariffs are working big time. Every country on earth wants to take wealth out of the United States always to our detriment. I say as they come, tax them, if they don't want to be taxed, let them make or build the product in the U.S. In either event, it means jobs and great wealth."

"Because of tariffs, we will be able to start paying down large amounts of the $21 trillion in debt accumulated, much by the Obama Administration while at the same time reducing taxes for our people. At minimum, we will make much better trade deals for our country."

Here now is Mark Avallone, President and Founder of Potomac Wealth Advisors. Mark, are you with us?

MARK AVALLONE, PRESIDENT AND FOUNDER, POTOMAC WEALTH ADVISORS: Yes. Good morning, good to be here.

MCDOWELL: Good morning. What do you -- what do you make of this? So far, I don't -- I don't think it's a stretch to say that the market has largely shrugged off what has been going on with the trade fight that started in the spring.

AVALLONE: Well it has shrugged it off, our market's up year-to-date across the board and China's is down. It's down 18 percent the beginning of the year and it's in bear market going back to 2017.

So the Trump strategy is to use our economic strength now while we have it to enact much needed and frankly, much deserved parity. He wants a fair playing field with China. The only problem with the trade policy is he dragged in the Canadians and the E.U. which then you have us against the world.

If we focus on China, keep it more of a microcosm then the stock market appears to say, "Hey, we can manage this. Our economy is strong enough and we'll push higher from here."

MCDOWELL: Mitch, how much runway is the market or investors going to give the Trump Administration because right now we've seen with the job's report on Friday we created on average 215,000 jobs every month, that's faster than the pace that we were at last -- last year, the first seven months of the year which is really incredible for an economy that's been in expansion mode since -- for nine years.

ROSCHELLE: The interesting thing would be in -- I think the reason why the market shrugged it off and to your point on runway is because corporate earnings have been so robust.

But what we're starting to see is the cost of the supply chain understand the market perspective on this, the cost in the supply chain to go up. And if they cannot pass those cost to the customer, meaning customers won't pay an increase price then we're going to see impact corporate profits.

The flip side is, if they can, we're going to see inflation. So, I think we're close to maybe in the next quarter getting to the point where the market's going to have a hard time turning off --

MCDOWELL: Well is that a lose lose because somebody bears that cost, either it's corporations or if it's the consumer. If it's the consumer, is it more -- if the companies can passed those cost on the consumer, is it more, I guess, the impact won't be as severe to the market.

ROSCHELLE: It will -- it certainly won't be. In fact, it will help grow revenue because they're charging more for the products. It may not necessarily help margin, but it will certainly help the top line.

But the challenge is going to be how much can you pay for (INAUDIBLE) before the market pushes back or there's another alternative that starts to erode sales. But Mark, I'm curious your perspective on that.

AVALLONE: Well if it does as you say raise the price of the end good and raising revenues for the corporation, then it is a tax on the consumer. Ultimately it is going to be a drag.

But I think the play here is that are the consumer wages are so strong, the individuals are flushed with cash, we can pay up for this without it slowing down our economy too much. China's limping along.

So one a one-on-one basis, we can power through this. If that wasn't the outlook, we would have seen the stock market pull back by now. The market looks forward and yet it's been up for the year. So I think all the news is out and Wall Street is saying the global growth story that we heard, the I.M. -- from the IMF this year for the G20, from we continue it here from the Fed, the global growth story is strong enough that even if price is raised, it's not going to slow down the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: Mitch already mentioned this, there's a story in the Wall Street Journal today, an article commenting on the strong earnings season. Profits surging at big U.S. firm, strong economy, and tax cuts, fuel gains, and embolden companies to raise prices.

This is a recent report by the UFDA showed nearly three million have come - - individuals have come all for food stamps since President Trump took office. Mark -- Mike Baker, you can see the world in terms of the business that you do.

And Mark briefly mentioned this, that we do have the upper hand because China is so weak right now, because the stock market is greater, their economy is growing a great deal slower, and they are wash in debt. So the timing of this that people act like President Trump might be rash, but there's some wiliness and some intelligence in why we pick right now to take this fight on.

BAKER: I think that's true. I'm heading to Beijing tomorrow morning for a week or so, very curious to kind of get the on the ground response from just the, you know, local folks in business about how they perceive this from their side.

I will say it's not in anybody's interest globally for -- to have an unstable Chinese economy, it just -- it just not. And so --

MCDOWELL: Do you think they blank though? That's been the question that we raise last week, do you think China blanks on this?

BAKER: I think ultimately they do because they're extremely pragmatic and they understand what a chaotic problem they could have if the economy continues to head south.

And with -- a question from Mar is, you mentioned mark the idea that we dragged in Canada and the E.U. into this overall trade issues, trade war, do you think that that was more of a negotiating ploy with the president in terms of overall objective for China or do you think in a sense, you know, there's not really a grand strategy here?

AVALLONE: Well it's tough to say with the president. Maybe he's trying to show the Chinese he's serious about this and hopefully, quietly behind the scenes reaching an agreement.

We saw that Mexico, we might update the NAFTA Agreement and start being on a friendly playing field again. That's really the hope. You really don't want to take on the entire world. It's either take on China, and focus on these legitimate inequities, technology transfer and others and let's have our allies with us as we try to take on China.

Remember, China's also unfair to the E.U., let's make the E.U. our ally against the number one trade offender and that is China.

CARTER: This is Lee Carter, I -- one of the things that I've been fascinated to watch is that most Americans really have been willing to give the president a long runway here and that's been really surprising because the most part people don't want to take short-term pain in order for the long-term gain.

And China's known to have a long gain, really long gain. We've got election cycle after election cycle after election cycle and investor seem to be giving in the past two. But I'm just wondering how long do you think Americans are going to give this runway before they're going to say, "Wait, this is too much?"

AVALLONE: Well, it's interesting that -- that's a great point because a lot of the Trump voters are the ones that are negatively impacted by this tariff skirmish. You have farmers in the Midwest that voted for Trump that are taking a lot of this.

And some of the manufacturing with the aluminum and steel tariffs could have gone against a lot of his base. But ironically, they are sticking with him and we haven't seen the weakness just yet. China on the other hand doesn't have an election in November nor will they have an election.

So their government can continue to be autocratic and weighed out. So if Trump's playing the long game, he doesn't really have the upper hand in that. I think trying -- we keep saying is, is China going to blink? That's the last thing we should say. China's never going to publicly blink.

We want to work diplomatically behind the scenes and hope to get a favorable outcome without letting the world thing we beat China or they blink because they're not going to blink publicly.

MCDOWELL: Would you add the stocks here Mark, U.S. stocks particularly with the -- again, over the weekend I think that Jamie Dimon the head of J.P. Morgan said that he -- that the -- this country should brace itself for five percent interest rates.

He said that he thinks that the tenure yield should be at four percent right now and we should brace for five, this is we're staring down $1 trillion annual budget deficits and the Treasury is going to be selling a whole wash of debt in the coming weeks.

AVALLONE: Well when I hear those Jamie Dimon comments I said perhaps. But we're in a global economy. With the tenure boomed and the tenure in Japan being, what, less than one half a percent close to zero in Japan.

So we cannot unilaterally raise our rates that rapidly, it's a global economy. There's a subtle currency we're going on where none of these other entities want to raise their currencies, they're not going to (INAUDIBLE) up interest rates. A five percent tenure is not going to happen.

We're lucky if we get to four percent in this country the way we have the foreign pressure in the currency and in the interest rate markets. I think if you invest, you have to look domestically. Our economy is too strong.

I think small caps which earn about 75 percent of their revenue here domestically versus the S&P500 which get about half of their revenues overseas, I think it's a safer place in case this trade skirmish continues.

And, again, since I don't see interest rates going anywhere near four percent in the next 12 months, I think the U.S. economy manages any rate hike and we continue to chug along.

MCDOWELL: Mark, thank you so much, Mark Avallone. And Mitch Roschelle, when you're talking about the debt, the one thing that's on your mind is the amount of supply coming in Treasury.

ROSCHELLE: And also, look who buys them, central bankers are the biggest buyers of our debt and it worries that we're sort of fighting with them on other issues. What if China decides to use how they behave the next Treasury auction as a -- as a weapon.

MCDOWELL: $769 billion in Treasury up for auction over what period of time? I'm reading an e-mail Mitch since --

ROSCHELLE: (INAUDIBLE) your head.

MCDOWELL: No, when is it coming on?

ROSCHELLE: I think it's over the next year. I think that according to the Journal but we can double check that. But that's a big chunk of treasuries that are up for sale and we could see rates go up.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I -- when people always point to Japan and a slow interest rates I'm like, "Yes." But Japan's kind of been in a recession for the last 30 years on and off.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. Since the 80s.

MCDOWELL: Like we don't -- yes, since the late 80s. We kind of hope that we're not Japan.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. Don't use -- don't use Japan as the benchmark please.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Thank you. Thank you very much. Coming up, death and destruction as an earthquake rocks the popular Indonesian resort island. More than 80 people dead. Officials expect that death toll to rise.

And another black eye for Wells Fargo, hundreds of people plunged into foreclosure unfairly because of a software glitch. The new fallout ahead.

MCDOWELL: A deadly powerful earthquake striking a tourist island in Indonesia. Kristina Partsinevelos has the details. Good morning Kristina.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. And that's right Dagen, at least 91 have been killed after a 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck the Indonesian island of Lombok, hundreds have been injured and thousands displaced as tourists flees the popular island.

The death toll is expected to rise as search and rescue teams expand their efforts. And they can't get a break because that area was still recovering from a deadly 6.4 magnitude earthquake that hit last week.

Goldman Sachs set to name a new co-head of its trading operation, the Wall Street Journal says Jim Esposito will be tapped for the position. The newspaper says the move follows months of leadership on certainty in Goldman's largest division.

Goldman's incoming CEO David Sullivan reportedly could make an announcement this morning. Shares of Goldman Sachs are eight percent this year.

And finally, Tom Cruise and Winnie the Pooh battles for first place at the weekend Box Office.

(VIDEO CLIP)

PARTSINEVELOS: And who do you think won? Tom Cruise came out on top. His new film Mission Impossible Fallout hanging on to the number one spot for the week, the second eek in a row breaking in an estimated $35 million.

Meanwhile, Disney's Christopher Robin fell short of expectations earning $25 million in its opening weekend. And last but not least, the new comedy film, The Spy Who Dumped Me brought home $12.4 million for a third place finish. Rounding up the top five, Mama Mia: Here We Go Ahead and the Equalizer 2. Have you guys any of you seen these movies over the weekend?

BAKER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Well you did -- did you, Mike Baker?

BAKER: Christopher Robin.

MCDOWELL: You did?

CARTER: You did?

BAKER: Well I got three little kids. It looks like I'm going to see Winnie the Pooh. Winnie the Pooh by the way in a real fight would kick Tom Cruise's ass. I don't know if I could say that but I just did.

MCDOWELL: You just said that.

BAKER: I just did. Sorry. There you go.

MCDOWELL: Wait, why would -- I would put my money on Eeyore versus Tom Cruise.

BAKER: Well, yes.

MCDOWELL: Eeyore is my spirit animal.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE)

BAKER: Here we go ahead.

MCDOWELL: Slow and grumpy morning, noon, and night grumpy. Eeyore's in it, isn't he?

BAKER: You know, it's --

ROSCHELLE: Don't ruin it for us.

BAKER: Yes, I won't -- I won't tell you how it ends, let me just put it that way. Right.

ROSCHELLE: Does he get the honey jar off his nose though?

BAKER: If you got kids, who can't like Winnie the Pooh, come on?

MCDOWELL: Would you pay to see Ethan Hunt in Mission Impossible?

BAKER: No. No. But if Damon makes another Bourne movie, I'm there.

MCDOWELL: OK.

BAKER: All right.

MCDOWELL: So Bourne over Mission Impossible.

BAKER: Yes. Yes.

MCDOWELL: All right. I'm coming with you on that Mike Baker. But I -- you frighten so, of course, I will --

BAKER: I'm sure.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, a new crisis for Wells Fargo, hundreds of people looking to save their homes are forced into foreclosure because of a computer glitch. The latest woes for Wells ahead.

And move to Italy and eat Nutella all day long, details on what some called the world's yummiest jobs next.

MCDOWELL: Wells Fargo under fire again, hundreds of people losing their homes due to a computer glitch. Gerri Willis, you can't make it up.

WILLIS: Here we go again, you got that right Dagen. Wells Fargo admitting to a glitch that led to hundreds of home for closures.

Now the bank says that a calculation error led to as many as 400 struggling home owners needlessly losing their homes to foreclosure, the culprit, a modification tool online that wrongly factored lawyer's fees into a formula that calculated government mortgages system in the wake of a housing crash.

As many as 650 applicants were incorrectly denied modifications. Now the details of this in a regulatory filing by the bank, the company setting aside $8 million in the second quarter to fix the problem which were works out to about $20,000 per home owner. But this isn't the first problem for Wells snapped by a long shot.

Check out this timeline of troubles for the bank and I should say here, we don't have everything in this timeline because you don't have time for everything in this timeline. A fake account scandal revealed in September of 2016, the SEC investigation of that account scandal in which bank employees open accounts customers didn't need and didn't want in return for bonuses.

But it wasn't just the consumer banking business an issue. In July 2017, allegations said the bank had properly sold auto insurance. That same year the bank was also accused of selling dangerous investments to brokerage clients.

The bank has been fined $1 billion for the -- from the CFPB for mortgage abuses but the list of troubles goes on in nearly every line of businesses seems to me including F.X., no matter where work -- look, whether the bank was dealing with consumers or was dealing with their -- with their institutional clients, big problems.

MCDOWELL: Lee, how did they handle it in terms of messaging because this just stinks to high heaven?

CARTER: You know, I think that for the most part they've done a pretty good job considering the magnitude of the problems that they've had. Now, the question I always have when you -- when you -- no matter how or who you message, the more scandals that happen, trust the road.

Like you've got to get it all out at some point. I think this is going to be -- this of all of the problems I think is going to hurt.

ROSCHELLE: And I think these and other stories are going to be rallying cry perhaps in the midterms around the deregulatory push that the administration has and this is the reason why you have regulations in the eyes of people who are in favor in regulations.

WILLIS: Well I mean -- look, they have tried to set the record straight here and move beyond it. And what's interesting to me Dagen, I know you watch this story very closely is that people haven't run away.

You know, the consumer is not gone from Wells Fargo. I mean, that's' where you would expect the pedal to really hit the metal as people see these headlines, that consumers would take their accounts elsewhere. We've some of that but not a ton of that.

MCDOWELL: It's inertia, that's part of it. But if -- in terms of big banks, they're just not that many in the country. But will you see people turning to these smaller community banks because they are everywhere. You're raising your hands.

BAKER: I'll put my -- I'll put my hand up because I'm one of those people that moved. We were --

CARTER: Really?

BAKER: -- with Wells Fargo for a long time and we went through that process. I can tell you what I think one of the reasons why people don't do it is because it's painful. But you -- you -- there's a lot of work involved and you're busy doing everything else in your day, right?

So all of a sudden you got to move your finances to a new institution. So -- but we did because after a while we just got fed up.

WILLIS: Well -- and you know look, this is going to go on, people are going to continue to watch this. The fees are still piling up. I mentioned the $1 billion from the CFPB, but they've got lots of other fines as well. And you better bet after this news they're going to have mre.

MCDOWELL: And I was thinking lawsuits. That --

CARTER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- you kick people out of their homes unfairly, the trial lawyers are running up.

WILLIS: They make people sign those agreements though to arbitrate. So that's one way they've stayed out of trouble in courthouses across the country.

MCDOWELL: OK. Good point. Good point. Did you move your business accounts too from Wells Fargo?

BAKER: No. No. The long-time personal finances, but I have businesses elsewhere, yes.

MCDOWELL: But not at Wells Fargo?

BAKER: That's a national security issue.

MCDOWELL: Gerri, great --

WILLIS: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Gerri Willis. Coming up, Senator Elizabeth Warren not backing down from the rumors that she is ready to run for president in 2020. Her new comments ahead.

And saying goodbye to an 80s TV icon, we look back at the life of Charlotte Rae.

(VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Good morning I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 6th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern.

China state media attacking President Trump over his proposed tariffs. The Communist Party's People's Daily saying that Trump was starring in his own street fighter style deceitful drama of extortion and intimidation. President Trump says that the tariffs are about getting America back on track.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: But America's economic surrender ended the day that I took office folks. Now after years of rebuilding foreign countries, we are finally rebuilding our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Futures are showing some gains across the board after a winning week for the markets last week, 25-point gain on the sow Futures at the moment. The Dow and S&P500 last week up five weeks in a row.

In Europe, we have some buying to tell you about as well. In England, France, and Germany, the biggest winner there, they're all up about 0.3 percent at the moment.

Asian markets, finishing mostly in the red, yesterday, the only winner there, the Hang Seng, up half of one percent.

Remembering Charlotte Rae, the star of the 1980s hit T.V. show, the Facts of Life, has died, at the age of 92. Charlotte Rae played Mrs. Garrett on that show. We will celebrate her life with smiles, coming up.

Moving onto California, wildfires still raging, one blaze growing to become the fourth largest in that state's history, we have the latest from California.

And hold the phone, new details out from Samsung, on its latest phone. We break down everything you need to know. And get those taste buds ready, the maker of Nutella has a job for you, for all of us.

To our top story this half hour, big tech gets political, Facebook, announcing its removing four pages belonging to Alex Jones, for "violating our hate speech and bullying policies." This follows Apple's move to erase Alex Jones' info wars podcast from its iTunes library.

Then onto Twitter, suspending Conservative Commentator, Candace Owens, for her response to a set of anti-white tweets by a New York Times editorial board member, the social media site, Twitter, later issuing an apology, but never once taking aim at the New York Times staffer for the original tweet.

Joining me now, Jessica Tarlov, Fox News Contributor and Matt Braynard, Republican Strategist, Former Trump Campaign, Data and Strategy Director, and Look Ahead America Executive Director, Jessica, let me start with you.

Again, if you've noticed, I've noticed on Twitter, just in the last couple of weeks, that all the Trump supporters have a big red x next to their name and to basically highlight what they see as censorship of Conservative content on Twitter.

JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I've noticed that too. It took me a couple of days to figure out what the X's meant.

MCDOWELL: But, again, it just makes a statement.

TARLOV: Oh, it definitely does. And picked them Socialists with the wilting flowers, it's interesting when you see these trends happen like that. I think it's a very serious issue that we certainly should be talking about. I think there's a difference between what went on with Alex Jones and what went on with Candace Owens.

Here, they certainly made a mistake, and obviously, their algorithms picked up what Candace was doing and she was making a point that I think does need to be made about Sarah Jones' tweets, which apparently go back to 2012, even it wasn't just the latest rash.

As for Alex Jones, I don't know if you saw last week, that he's actually suing parents whose child died in Sandy Hook for a hundred thousand dollars to cover -- help him cover legal fees. That family was forced to move six or seven times, because of the fact that Alex Jones was not only spreading lies at them.

You know, he said that they were actor -- child actors there, but releasing information as to where they lived so they haven't been safe and they've been moving with their daughter who's the same age, she was a twin with their son that died. So, there's a little bit of a difference there.

MCDOWELL: And I think that very often when you see companies shutting down a podcast like with Apple and what Facebook did, Matt, it's -- they are covering their you-know-whats because of legal liability.

In some instances, that's my go-to thought, but I will say in terms of the treatment of Conservatives, broadly speaking, looking at the Candace Owens situation, it actually fuels the Trump base because they do feel like they're being silenced and it actually makes them more -- I was talking to Lee Carter and Lee's going to get into this as the show moves on.

But, you look at -- she was testing these rallies and people are more devoted to Trump than ever before. What say you, Matt?

MATT BRAYNARD, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, LOOK AHEAD AMERICA: Yes, I think the real question here is, like, who's going to be next, because at least in Alex Jones' case, the language that they used was that, you know, it was hate speech. And that's a very broad term and it's not really clear on any given day what that means to these tech companies.

It's important to remember that the personnel is policy and stacked from the bottom to the top of the corporate leadership. Department heads of all these tech companies, they are hard-core leftists.

And if this is just the first example of them censoring somebody or going after somebody, it just makes me wonder who is next, whose unfavorable opinions will be targeted next for de-platforming by Apple or anyone of these larger -- other large social media companies and will people who opposed go immigration or question the latest on gender politics or pro- lifers.

I mean, at what point does it cross that "hate speech" line, especially relying on far left-organizations like the Southern Poverty Law Center to define exactly what hate speech is, which includes this network here.

MCDOWELL: Well, Matt, what I'm saying is that, actually, that the outrage at the social media sites is actually -- it's somehow in an upside down world. It works to the candidates' benefit. It works to President Trump's benefit.

The laziness of many people on television media because it's just -- it's easier to accuse President Trump of having lost his mind or being deranged or being mentally ill, than to actually do policy work and understand, say, his trade policy.

What I'm saying is the outrage generated by these social media platforms in trying to censor Conservatives. It actually whips up the base.

BRAYNARD: I can see that there is definitely some pushback. And when you -- when these stories come out, it certainly does make people much more skeptical of these large hegemonies of technology. But it does concern us, though, that they are essentially removing platform.

The platform in many cases of funding and in the cases of Google, for removing advertising options for right-wing Conservative voices, patriotic voices, along with --

You know, just deleting podcast, whole cell, not particular ones, but the entire podcast series of Alex Jones. And not to defend him but it does -- it is a troubling sign, as if there's no appeal in Facebook or Twitter takes away your account or blocks you. There's no remedy, you're just stuck with it and because you have just a --

MCDOWELL: With the podcast, you can deliver your own podcast and you can still download -- like there are myriad podcast apps that you can use to listen to a podcast. It doesn't -- it might -- being on Apple's platform, it does generate listeners.

But I just want to make that point that if you can put it up on website and people can listen to and watch what you put out there, because quite frankly, the first amendment.

But I want to switch gears to Senator Elizabeth Warren, fuelling rumors, Jessica Tarlov, over a 2020 run, this is over the weekend, here is what she had to say, she's not afraid to be the underdog.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), MASSACHUSETTS: It won't be easy. We are going to have to fight uphill. But me, I'm going up that hill and I hope you are too. And I hope that when you do, you'll reach your hand out and bring someone else along for the climb.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Jessica, that was the Netroots conference, down in New Orleans, I know you were glued to the internet watching those -- watching those --

TARLOV: I didn't go out all weekend.

MCDOWELL: There's a lot of slogan there, but what about policy?

TARLOV: Well, she certainly has a set of policies and they're very aligned with Bernie Sanders' policies and the Dems Socialist line, you can listen to Cynthia Nixon, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, for instance. You can hear what Elizabeth Warren is all about, and frankly, she has been incredibly vocal for a long time now.

And you do know what she stands for. The Democrats feel, that I think the most I've seen is a list of about 35, it is wide. Apparently, Joe Biden is the leader right now, in most of the polling, that seems -- I really do love Joe Biden, but it feels like we need a fresher face, someone that --

MCDOWELL: Well, let me just be blunt, how excited are the Democrats about running an old-white guy?

TARLOV: I -- not great.

MCDOWELL: He would appeal to some of the same base that President Trump does, mid-Western grit --

TARLOV: And Obama's base as well. He is utterly beloved in the party, and actually, a lot of Republicans are a fan of him, as well, you can't deny what kind of great person he is. I think age is an issue whether you're a man or a woman, going into this primary, I think, will you see Kamala Harris taking a more prominent role, really putting herself out there, I think she'll be there.

I'm really interested to see President Obama has been meeting with a lot of big-city mayors, I wonder where that'll go. I don't think Eric Garcetti or Mitch Landrieu will be our nominee, but I certainly to counter the businessman president, to have someone with executive experience, I think, is worthwhile.

MCDOWELL: Here, I'm going to go out on a limb and say, one individual who's not going to run for the presidency, would be Rahm Emanuel --

TARLOV: Yes.

MCDOWELL: in terms of mayors in the city of Chicago, and he can't even -- and he can't even stop the death toll from rising from gun violence, we saw that over the weekend. Matt, your reaction to that, because Jessica did mention, age is an issue in terms of the Democrats, but then, everybody seems to turn their attention to Alexandria --

TARLOV: Ocasio-Cortez.

MCDOWELL: Ocasio-Cortez, thank you very much, who brags about having an economics degree, but doesn't know how the unemployment rate is calculated.

BRAYNARD: Yes. I think that throwing names out like Joe Biden and Liz Warren, is just a sign of weakness of the field. They really don't have any strong candidates. And honestly, for them to suggest Liz Warren as a credible candidate, somebody whose name we would never know had she not lied about her ethnicity to go --

TARLOV: Matt --

BRAYNARD: It's just a sign of pure weakness on their part. And I would love to be throwing the briar patch of running a general election against Liz Warren, but i don't think the Democratic Party is even that suicidal. But I could be wrong.

TARLOV: Well, I don't know if it's suicidal, you are wrong, and you are also wrong about Liz Warren's name only being related to the fact that she "lied about her--

BRAYNARD: She was --

TARLOV: Listen.

BRAYNARD: She got a job at Harvard because of that and that allowed her to run to the senate in Massachusetts.

TARLOV: This is a whole other segment that we should have, I think that's incredibly irresponsible thing to say.

BRAYNARD: I don't think we can bring up Liz Warren without -- it's the truth. I mean, I don't think we can -- I don't think we can let that slide. I mean, it's --

TARLOV: I know that's the kind of campaign that you would run and if, you know, work for President Trump, again, I'm sure you'll be out there on the front lines doing something like that. I just don't think it's responsible

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I will weigh in on something, since this is a business show, this is -- since this is a business show, I will weigh in on something that I hear more and more from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, I want to get her name right, and Bernie Sanders and even Elizabeth Warren, Medicare for all.

TARLOV: Right.

MCDOWELL: So we now know how much that's going to cost.

TARLOV: 30 trillion, thirty-two.

MCDOWELL: Yes, almost $33 trillion over just the first 10 years. You would need to double what the federal government collects in individual and corporate taxes to pay for it, and it still wouldn't cover the cost of it.

TARLOV: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And this is Medicare, is going broke in eight years. Medicare, the hospital trust fund is broke in eight years. We haven't fixed it, nobody talks about fixing it, but now, we're talk about Medicare for all. I mean, it's a great tag line, Jessica --

TARLOV: Of course, it is.

MCDOWELL: But there's no plan to pay for it.

TARLOV: Well, I'm sure they will get to you. Bernie Sanders has been out there, pumping it up. I think there was report from the Cato Institute about Medicare for all, conversations with the Koch brothers. Listen, I think that that interview with Trevor Noah was disastrous.

For the Dems Socialist platform, there is now Medicare for all caucus, but if you look at races like Ohio, tomorrow, for instance, special election there. Danny O'Connor is out there saying, not going to work, let's fix Obamacare, which is exactly where Democrats should be, going into the 2018 election and making smart decisions.

MCDOWELL: Well, let me -- we'll get into that, Jessica, because actually, we got such good news on those premium increases. The premium increases that we've heard about in some states last week are lower than they've been in recent years. The premium increases in the Obamacare plans, they're actually falling in some areas.

TARLOV: Well, Obamacare has lowered the cost of healthcare across the country in terms of the rate at which -- the rate at which healthcare costs are increasing, lowered under President Obama, fact-check me, all day, on that, Matt.

BRAYNARD: Oh, yes. The cost totally dropped, just as he promised they would, dropped by an average of $2,500 per family, which he promised, absolutely not, they continue to increase. And just having you repeat that, it's almost like getting banned on Twitter, it just excites Conservatives more because --

TARLOV: Conservatives hate me anyway.

MCDOWELL: But Matt -- but Matt --

BRAYNARD: I don't think they know who you are.

MCDOWELL: my point in bringing up the lower increases in premiums by some insurers in Obamacare plans, that benefits the Conservatives who failed the Republicans, who fail to really fix Obamacare, except for the fact that they repealed the individual mandate and the Trump administration through rule-making, has opened the door for shorter-term health plans.

So I'm saying that that actually benefits Republicans, particularly those in the Senate, who fail to get through the repeal and replace that passed in the House, final word?

BRAYNARD: Yes, I just want to say, I think, you're right there. It will be helpful but ultimately, what's important is the fact that healthcare costs can be offset by the fact that there are more Americans employed more than ever.

The economy is growing faster than it ever has, in a long time, and a lot of that credit goes to the President, and that's going to go down the ticket when people decide who to vote for this November and perhaps, tomorrow, on the special election.

TARLOV: Healthcare issue, number one, in a lot of races, special elections and primaries, Democrats are slaying on the healthcare issue.

MCDOWELL: I will add this, I sat on this set with Kellyanne Conway right when she joined the Trump campaign and the Hillary Clinton campaign underestimated how much that would impact who people voted for that November, and so the Republicans should not underestimate it in this midterm election. Jessica Tarlov, Matt Braynard, thank you both.

TARLOV: Thanks, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Coming up, the California wildfires take on epic new proportions as one blaze nearly doubles in size, we have the latest. And Samsung's new Galaxy Note 9, details are leaked from an interesting source, more on that, in minutes.

MCDOWELL: One of the world's greatest chefs has passed away. Kristina Partsinevelos has the details, Kristina?

KRISTINA PATSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Dagen, Joel Robuchon was named the -- the "chef of the century" by the famous French restaurant guide Gault Millau in 1990. He was known for mashed potatoes among other dishes and had open restaurants in cities across the globe including Paris, Monaco, Hong Kong, Las Vegas, Tokyo and New York. His restaurants currently hold a record of 32 Michelin stars; he also mentored numerous other chefs such as T.V. personality: Gordon Ramsey. Robuchon died at 73 after a long battle well cancer.

And fans are also remembering Charlotte Rae actress best known as Mrs. Garrett on the long-running sitcom, "The Facts of Life" has died.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLOTTE RAE, ACTRESS: I have to get going. I got to make the bed, back in the rug, do the laundry, scrub the floors, clean the windows, everything has got to be perfect.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PARTSINEVELOS: Her family says, she died peacefully in her home in Los Angeles yesterday. The cause of her death has not been released but last year she did reveal she had been diagnosed with bone cancer. The Tony and Emmy-nominated actress' career spent six decades. Charlotte Rae was 92 years old.

And catastrophic wildfires continue to ravage California with one doubling in size over the weekend, making it the fourth largest wild fire in state history. There are now a total of 17 fires burning across the state claiming the lives of seven people and destroying thousands of acres. Meanwhile, President Trump has declared a state of emergency in California ordering federal funding to help with the recovery efforts but he also tweeted: "California wildfires are being magnified and made so much worse by the bad environmental laws which aren't allowing massive amounts of readily available water to be properly utilized. It is being divert into the Pacific Ocean. Must also treat clear to stop fire spreading."

And on a lighter note, we'll switch over to Nutella. If you love Nutella, then you're about to discover your dream job. The Ferrero company, maker of Nutella and Ferrero Rocher chocolates is looking for 60 sensory judges who will get paid to taste its product after, of course, you need a three- month rigorous training course. 40 of the 60 people will go on to become testers. But there's a catch, you have to be willing to relocate to Ferrero's headquarters in Alba, Italy. So, I don't think this is too bad of a gig. What do you think, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: I defer to my baker on that. And thank you for the Joel Robuchon --

PARTSINEVELOS: I don't know why I said it like that. I know -- it just came out naturally, I'm sorry.

MCDOWELL: You know, he's French.

PARTSINEVELOS: He is French.

MCDOWELL: And you have to say it --

PARTSINEVELOS: And then I was going to say -- I don't know, I was just on a roll there, just going back. Quebec French.

MCDOWELL: We'll take it any day. Nutella taster?

BAKER: Turn it into a reality show, right? 40 of the 60 contestants get to on to become actual testers. You got a three-months training. This is ready made. You know, reality T.V. is all about finding something that's already happening and throw in cameras in front of it. So, that's what I'm saying and, and otherwise I'm not a big fan of Nutella, what can I say?

MCDOWELL: Because something is deeply wrong with you.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Coming up, Warren Buffett becomes one of biggest winners as Apple hits $1 trillion in market value. After the magical milestone, everyone has predictions for the tech giant's next move. We take a closer look next.

MCDOWELL: Samsung's new Galaxy Note 9 launches on Thursday and the details are being leaked by Samsung. The box with the device was spotted at Russian store revealing a 6.4-inch display, a dual rear camera with 12 mega-pixels, and an 8 mega-pixels front selfie camera. As previously reported, the note's pen will have remote-control type functionality.

Meantime, Apple making investors happy after becoming the world's first $1 trillion company last week. One of the winners is Warren Buffett who (INAUDIBLE) are half way owned to five percent stake in Apple, now worth nearly $50 billion. Joining me now, CFRA Senior Equity Analyst, Angelo Zino. Angelo, Buffett usually shies away from tech stocks. This is a winner for him and also, what do you make about the Samsung phone given Apple a run for its money.

ANGELO ZINO, SENIOR EQUITY ANALYST, CFRA: Yes, absolutely. So, you know, in terms of Samsung and these leaks going on, you wonder if there're really, you know, leaks because, you know, at this point in time we continue to see the stuff -- you know, ahead of these launches, you know, year in and year out. But that being said, I mean, when we look at kind of some of the details of the event coming here on Thursday, little that, you know, really gets us excited on the front of Samsung.

That being said, as far as Apple is concerned -- I mean, the results last week were absolutely spectacular. Looking at Warren Buffett here, I mean, I think he continues to kind of cement and put kind of the cherry on the top as far as Apple is concerned. Him being the third largest investor there. He is just naturally going to continue to up his stake just via the buybacks you see from Apple here. But, you know, all in all, we continue to believe cash is king and Apple is here to stay with this trillion-dollar valuation.

MCDOWELL: Well, I think Warren Buffett -- this is about Apple and not Buffett. Buffett is like a molt to a flame in terms of seeking media attention. He's going to glom onto Apple's success. I'm not dismissing the fact that he has stake in Apple, but again, this is Apple's story not Buffet's story.

BAKER: No question. Angelo, just take a look at Apple for a second, what's next? So, we're talking about Samsung, and that's just more product innovation. Is there around product innovation? Do they stay with the customer space, do they branch out the way Amazon has in terms of having cloud business which is really a business to business, business?

ZINO: Yes. So, when we look at Apple here, it's funny because most people look at Apple and they say, hey, this is a one-hit wonder kind of company, it's the iPhone and that's it. And, you know, we continue to believe when we look at Apple the next step forward for them continues to be on the wearable side; that grew 60 percent year over year. We expect something along the lines of augmented reality glasses by 2020.

MCDOWELL: Because that was such a winner for Google. Those Google glass - - died on the vine.

ZINO: Right. But, you know, we do think Apple is going to do a lot better. We're going to have 5D eventually roll out. We think the capability of 5D along with these A.R. glasses will be a big hit for Apple over time. I think also, of course, that service's business which grew north of 30 percent as they shift toward more kind of subscription-based offerings, I think that's the model for Apple.

MCDOWELL: Angelo good to see you, Angelo Zino, take care. Still ahead, it's National Root Beer Float Day. We're raising a glass to this American classic, next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MCDOWELL: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 6th, your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern. Escalating trade tensions.

urn:contentItem:5V9P-JV81-JBKM-D0MP-00000-00Tough tech regulator charts her legacy2019-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:53ZLexisNexisROP 01 ZONEPg. A 7Tough tech regulator charts her legacyKELVIN CHANThe Associated Press

COPENHAGEN, Denmark - Silicon Valley's notorious nemesis, Margrethe Vestager, plans to end her term as the European Union's antitrust enforcer this year with a bang, laying out a long-term plan to intensify scrutiny of the world's big tech companies.

As the EU's competition commissioner, Vestager is arguably the world's most important tech regulator. Since 2014, she has slapped Google with eye-popping multibillion-dollar antitrust penalties, ordered Apple and Amazon to pay back taxes and fined Facebook over its WhatsApp acquisition - flagship enforcement cases that have struck fear into Silicon Valley while drawing attention in Washington, D.C.

Now, in her final year in office, the 50-year-old Danish politician is laying the groundwork for a new phase of regulation beyond the end of her term in October.

She's planning a report meant to guide EU competition policies in the era of digitization. Feedback from companies, business groups and experts shows many see the need for more regulation and when it's published in March, the report by three expert advisers will reflect the need for new or tougher rules, she told The Associated Press in a recent interview.

"The most important thing is that the majority of input is pro-enforcement," Vestager said during one of her frequent visits to Copenhagen from her Brussels base. The digital technology industry can no longer be allowed to shape itself, she added. "We are way beyond that."

It's unclear yet what shape the new enforcement will take but it may not bode well for the big U.S. technology companies that have landed in Vestager's crosshairs.

Vestager has cultivated a down-to-earth image - she likes to knit elephants during meetings - that belies her formidable powers of enforcement.

She opened three antitrust cases against Google, including one that resulted in a record 4.3 billion euro ($5 billion) fine for forcing cellphone makers to use the internet giant's software on Android phones. Another 2.4 billion euro ($2.8 billion) penalty was punishment for manipulating shopping search results. She aims to wrap up a probe before her term ends of whether Google blocked rivals from its AdSense ad service.

Vestager ordered Apple to pay back up to 13 billion euros ($15 billion) in back taxes from Ireland. Apple CEO Tim Cook called it "total political crap" and President Donald Trump referred to her as the "tax lady" who "really hates the U.S."

The EU competition commissioner, with a 900-strong staff, is unusually powerful in the Brussels bureaucracy because it can enforce bloc-wide rules, giving it the power to take on countries and companies. Other departments typically share regulatory duties with national governments.

Vestager's job includes approving or rejecting mergers and investigating cartels and antitrust behavior. She also makes sure EU states don't give tax breaks to individual companies that are not available to other corporations - legitimate business strategy in the U.S. but illegal in Europe.

A lot of attention is now falling on data, the commodity that drives the digital economy.

Information collected by web browsers, apps, smartphones and other devices can be enormously valuable to companies because they can provide insight about, for example, an individual's buying habits and movements. Data can power artificial intelligence or be used to show targeted advertisements. Vestager is concerned that a small group of companies could corner the market and abuse their power.

She started confronting the problem with an informal probe launched last year into whether online shopping giant Amazon is using data to gain an edge on third-party merchants, who are both its customers and rivals. She hopes to decide within six months whether to open a formal investigation.

Many people still aren't sure how to take control of their personal information. New European privacy rules introduced last year were a start, obliging companies to be more transparent with customers about what they do with people's data. But consumers are often still overwhelmed by detailed consent forms for third-party tracking on each new site they visit or the fine print of an app's service terms.

Vestager, a member of a small left-wing political party who believes in free markets, said the private sector can play a role in finding solutions.

"I think you need products that will help you exercise your rights. Independent digital assistants that will make sure that your privacy settings are maintained no matter where you go. That kind of stuff," she said.

Vestager, whose party was founded by her great-grandfather, was Denmark's deputy prime minister and economy minister before taking up her post in Brussels in late 2014. She reportedly keeps a sculpture of a hand with an extended middle finger in her office, a gift from a Danish trade union angered by her welfare cuts.

She's said to be one of the inspirations for the lead character in the Danish TV show "Borgen," about an ambitious minor politician trying to become the country's first female prime minister.

Although Vestager's term runs out in October, she's hoping for a second stint, an unlikely prospect because her party is out of power in Denmark and its prospects look uncertain in upcoming elections. The EU's executive commissioners are nominated by their country's governments.

"Sometimes things are unlikely but not impossible," Vestager said. "I'm in the middle of something and we're not done yet," she added, referring to the new era of digital regulation.

Vestager brushes off criticism that she's stifling innovation by targeting U.S. companies to help prop up European firms. She has also taken on Starbucks, McDonald's and this month opened an investigation into Nike's tax arrangements. But other targets have included Italian automaker Fiat and Russian gas giant Gazprom.

"When you look at our cases, you'd see that what they have in common is not nationality. It's the fact that they're multinationals."

Her aim, she says, is to keep competition fair.

"That was the idea before the world became digital," Vestager said. "And it becomes an even more important idea when the world becomes digital because things are so fast moving."

urn:contentItem:5X2V-Y0H1-JDJN-618D-00000-00Tough times for Big Tech amid a growing trust deficit2019-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:53ZLexisNexisTough times for Big Tech amid a growing trust deficit

viewpoint

The Big Tech, despite its overarching global reach, is facing tough times with a growing trust deficit, both from the users and regulators.
More so in the European Union, which has been the most aggressive jurisdiction so far in trying to rein in superstars like Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.


As Apple fights a $14.4bn tax case, the world's biggest, at the EU General Court in Luxembourg, here's in the inevitable question: Are the tech giants monopolies?
They are powerful, no doubt. Google and Facebook together controlled 60% of mobile ad revenue and 51% of digital ad revenue globally in 2018, according to eMarketer. In the US, Apple has about 45% of the smartphone market; about 47% of all US e-commerce sales go through Amazon.com.
Under modern antitrust enforcement, however, those percentages alone aren't enough to alarm regulators in the US. What's illegal is for a monopoly to abuse its market power to prevent rivals from threatening its position.
US courts ruled Microsoft did so in the 1990s.
But the EU law sets a lower bar for finding abuse of dominance. It's evidenced by three antitrust actions against Google in as many years carrying penalties that total $9.3bn.
Interestingly, the US chose not to bring charges against Google for the same conduct the EU found illegal.
The US Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission, which both have a mandate to enforce antitrust laws, are now working together to ramp up oversight of the technology giants.
In Asia, Japan's Fair Trade Commission says Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon need to be examined for possible abuse of their market dominance. South Korea's commission was reported last year to be looking into whether Google Korea was abusing its market position to pressure local game companies to upload their products only onto the Google Play platform.
In China, censorship and government control over Internet access have made it difficult for US techies to compete with the likes of Alibaba, Baidu and Tencent.
For sure, tech giants like Amazon and Facebook have leverage over both producers and consumers. They are also growing by snapping up potential rivals that might threaten market share. Data compiled by Bloomberg show the big five - Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft - have made 431 acquisitions worth $155.7bn over the last decade.
The companies also have control over vast amounts of data about their customers, raising concerns about threats to privacy.
The Silicon Valley executives are waking up to the backlash, striking a more conciliatory note and saying they want to work with authorities on a range of challenges. They argue that their dominance is hardly durable because barriers to entry are low for new competitors.
Google is fond of saying competition is just "one click away."
Fundamentally, social media users are driven by the same ancient desire: Human Connection. But that has for long been crowded out by addictive technology, amazing products and invasive corporate branding.
Longer term, the inescapable truth for the Big Tech is growing loud and clear: Techies can thrive only if people and regulators trust them. Amid a growing backlash, tech superpowers will need to figure out how to regain that trust.


Gulf Times Newspaper 2019

urn:contentItem:5XMH-FHV1-F03R-N45D-00000-00Towards a New Model of Data Ownership2019-11-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:53ZLexisNexisTowards a New Model of Data OwnershipJC Gaillard

Nov 30, 2019( Business 2 Community.com: http://www.business2community.com Delivered by Newstex) In anything but name, data is today's most used currency.In the current business paradigm, structured by big tech firms over a decade ago and replicated since by a number of online platforms, individuals willingly provide their personal information in exchange for a service. Personal data is subsequently repackaged - anonymised or not - and sold to advertisers and marketers. Some form of equilibrium establishes itself - in theory - between convenience and value for the users, to whom the services appear to be free, and financial rewards for the platforms which monetize the personal data collected to generate revenues.

In reality, the balance has been tilted over time in colossal proportions towards tech firms, whose valuations and profits have soared to historic heights as a result. Yet it seems that this model may be reaching crisis point. The Pew Research Center recently reported that 64% of Americans have personally experienced a major data breach. And beyond technical and financial considerations, this also impacts confidence negatively, as highlighted by the Axios-Harris Poll 100[1], suggesting that Americans consider data privacy as the top priority companies should address. This follows a record number of data breaches reported since 2016, in particular in the US. Following scandals such as the one surrounding Facebook and Cambridge Analytica, people have become increasingly aware of their online vulnerability and distrust [2]for large platforms is setting in more widely. The unavoidable rise of the Internet of Things will only make the issue more complex, as increasingly more intrusive and personal data will start to be collected about each of us — sometimes unbeknownst to us. Smart speakers, for example, bring intensive, real-time data collection to the comfort of our own living-rooms. This poses new challenges around the issue of consent and privacy: Why would you agree to have your conversation with your friends recorded simply because they own a certain type of smart assistant device? The EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), was a first step to ensure individuals' hold over their data. Yet, it remains a European initiative and it is still too early[3] to draw conclusions on its actual impact. In some industries, the quality expectations around the data required are so high that organisations willingly pay for it. This is the case for example in academic research in which field experiments often require highly precise data. Researchers usually conduct deeply informative surveys on a wide number of participants (to obtain representative samples) who are remunerated for their answers. If big tech firms were to move towards similar business models where they pay their users for their personal data, could it be a first step towards more transparency and the rebuilding of trust? (a key factor for their long-term success, and the digital transformation of society at large, free of excessive regulation). The question around data monetization should be at the heart of the evolution of the tech industry for the next decade, but how can it be fair for all, transparent and work at scale? A first approach to this question could be a top-down valuation of personal data established by online platforms. For example, economists drafted an experiment to value the free services, currently subsidized by the trading of personal data, of some web platforms. Participants on average responded that they were willing to leave Facebook for 110$ and Whatsapp for 600$[4] - thus valuing the personal data they deliberately provide to those platforms at those prices. Such model would however require a tougher enforcement of cybersecurity measures to guarantee that data usage is - and remains - as authorized by the user. As platforms would now be paying for our data, chances are that they would be able to use it but not possess it. In case of data breaches, they would therefore incur a greater liability with respect to their users who will now own and 'lend' their data. An alternative to this top-down model thought by and for large platforms is nonetheless possible. The tokenization[5] - the process of replacing and valuing data with a secured identification symbol - offers such perspective. If tokens were to be backed by personal data and decentralized into a public blockchain, a new, bottom-up, market mechanism could emerge. Cryptocurrencies might be a channel through which individuals value data. Large platforms needing to access and crawl data, such as Facebook or Google, would purchase the token corresponding to personal data directly to their miners (their users), in a secured way. In turn, the aggregation of tokens sold by individuals and purchased by firms would generate a new market thereby establishing a natural valuation of available tokens. Such mechanism offers interesting perspectives as users would easily track their personal data value but also actively engage in the data market over which they will be able to share directly the growing benefits. Yet answering the question of scalability isn't that easy. The boom and bust witnessed by the ICO market in 2018 proved that the relative convenience and liquidity of tokens can easily lead to large speculative trends. And while trading with cryptocurrencies which did not back highly tangible products or services had no real impact besides financial losses and ecological damages, a similar situation with our personal data would present very high risks for society. The scalability of such project thus presents as many hopes as risks - that shall be further investigated before diving in a new paradigm. Originally published here[6]. urn:contentItem:60JM-21K1-F00C-653P-00000-00Towards a new resiliency in the financial system2020-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:53ZLexisNexisTowards a new resiliency in the financial system

The webinar hosted by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) Sri Lanka in association with the Daily FT and CIMA explored the topic 'Towards a new resiliency in the financial system'. The session was moderated by ICCSL Chairman Dinesh Weerakkody and Standard Chartered Bank former economist Samantha Amerasinghe.

Our financial system has proved very resilient over the past 50 years. No reason to doubt it will bounce back after this crisis. The 'bounce back' is the unknown this time. Little of what we know, are familiar with and can deal with successfully, will be the same as before - customers, demand, value propositions, savings habits, revenue streams. An eminent panel which included Dr. Indrajit Coomaraswamy former Governor Central Bank of Sri Lanka, and a cross-section of business leaders from the banking sector, consulting firms, academia and multilateral institutions shared their invaluable insights on building resiliency in the financial system.

The panellists shed light on how businesses and countries are navigating through these challenging times, this so-called paradigm shift brought about by COVID-19. It was clear from the remarks of the panellists that resilience in the financial system is imperative to weather the storms in this era of disruption.

Opportunities and threats for the financial sector

Dr. Coomaraswamy shared his insights on the opportunities and threats for the financial sector stating that he sees two mitigating factors - first the medical aspects of the pandemic have been handled well and he expressed confidence that we should see a recovery if we are able to contain the pandemic. As the economy was not in a sound position pre-COVID, Sri Lanka will need to undertake structural reforms and have a sound medium-term macroeconomic framework in place to ensure a robust 'bounce back'. The second mitigating factor is that 70-75% of aggregate demand is accounted for by domestic demand. In normal circumstances this would be a drag on growth but at this juncture, being insulated from the external sector is an advantage.

He also opined that banks have played a unique role in Sri Lanka, while in other countries governments and central banks have taken the lead in terms of providing fiscal stimulus to keep businesses and households afloat. In Sri Lanka, the government has played a crucial role but it has been constrained by a severe lack of fiscal space. Dr. Coomaraswamy also asserted that the fiscal constraints afflicting the country are not the responsibility of one government but the collective failure of a succession of governments over the decades. He emphasised that all banks must do the maximum to ensure that asset quality does not deteriorate to the point where solvency of banks becomes a threat. Dr. Jameel Khadaroo, former Deputy Governor at the Central Bank of Mauritius also underscored the importance of rethinking structural policies to adapt to the 'new normal'.

Presenting the right picture to potential investors

CA President Manil Jayasinghe stressed the importance of presenting the 'right picture to potential investors' in terms of impairment provisioning. He commented that the moratoriums ending in September 2020 should not impact impairment provisioning. If credit risk in banks has worsened, then provisions need to be put in place now. Banks should not 'hide behind the moratorium' and subsequently have huge provisions when the moratorium ends.

What Sri Lanka needs to do after the crisis

Given the huge push globally to keep SMEs alive during this pandemic, IFC South Asia Regional Manager Rolf Behrndt highlighted that the IFC has initiated an $ 8 billion COVID fund to provide liquidity to help clients in the financial sector as a conduit to reach SMEs. Behrndt shared his thoughts on what Sri Lanka needs to do to rebound after the crisis; he asserted that Sri Lanka needs to move towards keeping value-added in manufacturing in the country and that there are opportunities in the agriculture and ICT sectors for Sri Lanka to move up the value chain in processing.

On the topic of making South Asia's economies more resilient to climate change, Behrndt commented that the sustainable finance roadmap launched by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka has the support of the IFC and in terms of renewable energy initiatives the IFC is working in close collaboration with the Government of Sri Lanka to add 380 MW of wind and solar power to the energy grid. Dr. Coomaraswamy added that the Central Bank is working closely with the IFC on Green Finance initiatives and has made some headway with banks in terms of tapping into global and regional funds.

Policies around data governance and open banking critical for financial sector

SCB CEO Bingumal Thewarathanthri stated that he would like to see banking sector practices evolving in a post-COVID world to embrace working from home, digitisation and the introduction of a digital ID for the country as a means to real time digital onboarding and cited policies around data governance and open banking as critical for the financial sector.

Thewarathanthri asserted that the pandemic has presented banks and corporates with a great opportunity to change work practices, but that it's imperative that they recognise the opportunity to partner with fintechs to provide value-added services to the bankable population. He also identified two critical success factors - the need for one integrated digital platform for all government payments and a cohesive approach in the banking sector with all banks working towards a common end-goal.

Reeling from the shock

On the question of what would be the 'new normal' for venture capital, private equity and hedge funds, McKinsey India Senior Partner Toshan Tamhane emphasised that though these firms are reeling from the shock caused by COVID-19 and are undergoing major stress in their ability to infuse new funds, they are also seeking new opportunities. Many companies are reassessing their supply chains and there has been significant interest in sectors such as pharmaceuticals, telecommunications, energy and renewables and financial services (banking and insurance).

Regulators have to grapple with creating the right framework for building stability given that from a resiliency standpoint threats to the financial sector such as cyber-attacks are often not in the country itself. He added, 'Innovation and stability will have to go hand-in-hand if we are to take advantage of this paradigm shift and the opportunities it has provided.'

Mastercard India Head of Engagement Santosh Kumar commented that he has seen a shift in the manner in which people transact on e-commerce and digital platforms away from tourism and hotels and towards essential items. Many merchants are also moving to the digital ecosystem. He further stated that big tech firms are disrupting the business model with more countries moving to a cashless society.

Investment in foresight capabilities is imperative

Dr. Noel Tagoe expressed his disappointment with governments across the world as he believes they have 'focused too much on saving lives and not enough on saving livelihoods.' Governments' in his view should 'see sooner, act faster'.

Dr. Tagoe stressed that investment in foresight capabilities is imperative if we are to move ahead of the curve and we have the tech tools to enable us to do so. He pointed out that there needs to be a 'cultural and mindset shift' for accountants and finance professionals to embrace new technologies. Furthermore, there needs to be policy flexibility and the international community must work together. Restoring trust and confidence in institutions through humility in leadership and transparency is the key to moving forward in the 'new normal'.

'New normal' unique to each country and sector

The concept of the 'new normal' was questioned by UNESCAP Economist Dr. Masato Abe, who stated that this phenomenon is unique to each country and sector. He stated that the ESG framework should be embedded in the political and financial systems and there needs to be greater collaboration among governments, financial institutions, businesses and SMEs to ensure that available funds are utilised in the region.

Moving to a multipolar world

Another salient point discussed by Dr. Coomaraswamy is that we are living in a world with an increased propensity for major shocks emanating from volatile capital flows, climate extremes and pandemics. We are moving to a multipolar world in which geopolitical risks have been elevated.

These major shocks translate into disruption of supply chains, international trade and technology. He opined that with all these sources of shocks becoming more prevalent, it is more difficult to deregulate the sector and said that it is 'better to err on the side of caution'. He pointed out that the drive for less regulation was evident even before COVID. The argument that global standards were designed for advanced economies and are too restrictive for developing economies has now gained momentum.

Dr. Coomaraswamy also emphasised that one needs to strike a balance between embracing technological change and creating the incentives to facilitate the banking sector to become more competitive in the fintech space, while maintaining stability in the system. 'Regulators need to make sure that they don't go too fast so as to undermine the traditional banking sector,' and to avoid major disruption. Dr. Khadaroo also recognised that regulators have a critical role to play in order to maintain the balance between ensuring innovation and preserving financial stability due to the disruption caused by fintechs.

When asked, 'What is the biggest constraint to achieving financial resilience?' Dr. Coomaraswamy mentioned that financial institutions need to be geared up to support their customers to deal with the following three key elements of the 'new normal' - digitalisation, the entire ESG agenda (not just climate change but also addressing concerns about inequality and diversity), and a less globalised, more local/regional world which will result in businesses having to deal with the trade-offs between efficiency and resilience in their supply chains. From the perspective of the payments industry, Santosh Kumar stated that the biggest constraint is anything that is a hindrance to the world moving to a digital, cashless society. Fractured regulation and the lack of investor confidence were also highlighted as constraints.

The new normal for Sri Lanka

To wrap up the session, a final question was posed to all panellists, 'What will the new normal look like for businesses once the crisis is over?' Toshan Tamhane emphasised the need for creative disruption and for understanding the 'new social contract,' the role of governments, corporations and talent in this new normal. Dr. Coomaraswamy summed up the session with one powerful takeaway.

He stated: 'While all panellists recognise the damage the pandemic has caused, there is also an underlying optimism that we can build back better, and that's what we need to do.'

The new normal for Sri Lanka, which we have been talking about for decades is to have a stable framework for monetary and fiscal policy and depoliticised institutions which delivers sound macroeconomic fundamentals and also a strong focus on structural reforms which will boost productivity and competitiveness of the economy.

Islington, London: Knowledge Transfer Network Limited has issued the following press release:

With the development of neurotechnology accelerating across the world, the UK has an exciting opportunity to help shape the development of a new wave of technologies, but the sector needs support now for this to become a reality. To read more about the exciting opportunities that lie await for the UK, and KTN’s proposed approach, read our new report here.

During the early years of the internet (in which ARPA, the predecessor of DARPA, played a central role in its development), it would have been hard to imagine some of its present-day applications. In the same way it is difficult to foresee the full impact neurotechnology might have in the future, but new platform technologies that can make use of neural data and link human brains to artificial intelligence are likely to have an enormous economical and societal impact.

No country yet has an unassailable lead in neurotechnology; however, ‘Big Tech’ (e.g Google, Amazon, Facebook, Apple, Microsoft, Tencent, Alibaba) and governments across the world, especially in the EU, US and China, are investing considerable amounts of money into its development.

With the emergence of new neural interface technologies, the UK has the opportunity to be home to a new generation of technology companies. In order to achieve this aspiration, significant investment is needed to develop and grow a UK ecosystem for neurotechnology. Moreover, by ensuring that the UK has a competitive neurotechnology sector, it will have an active role in the development of new international frameworks in ethics, regulations and data security. The importance of this is cast into sharper focus when considering some of the possible risks associated with neurotechnology, such as thoughts and emotions being monitored or even manipulated by companies, governments or others.

The recent decision to remove all Huawei equipment from UK 5G networks by 2027 demonstrates the government’s commitment to protect the UK’s data from external threats. It is essential that that the government takes an early lead in safeguarding neural data. The Royal Society’s iHuman report sets out a series of recommendations around the use and protection of neural data.

With the development of neurotechnology accelerating across the world, the UK has an exciting opportunity to help shape the development of a new wave of technologies, but the sector needs support now for this to become a reality.
